content.content:
1→# local-web-services
     2→
     3→Run your AWS CDK and Terraform applications locally. local-web-services reads your CDK cloud assembly or Terraform configuration and spins up local emulations of API Gateway, Lambda, DynamoDB, SQS, SNS, S3, Step Functions, Cognito, EventBridge, SSM Parameter Store, Secrets Manager, and more — so you can develop and test without deploying to AWS.
     4→
     5→## Try It Out
     6→
     7→### CDK Sample Project
     8→
     9→Clone the [CDK sample project](https://github.com/local-web-services/sample-project) — a serverless order processing system with API Gateway, Lambda, DynamoDB, SQS, S3, SNS, and Step Functions:
    10→
    11→```bash
    12→git clone https://github.com/local-web-services/sample-project.git
    13→cd sample-project
    14→npm install
    15→npx cdk synth
    16→```
    17→
    18→Start the local environment:
    19→
    20→```bash
    21→uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev
    22→```
    23→
    24→### Terraform Sample Project
    25→
    26→Clone the [Terraform sample project](https://github.com/local-web-services/sample-project-terraform) — the same order processing system built with Terraform:
    27→
    28→```bash
    29→git clone https://github.com/local-web-services/sample-project-terraform.git
    30→cd sample-project-terraform
    31→terraform init
    32→```
    33→
    34→Start the local environment, then apply:
    35→
    36→```bash
    37→# Terminal 1: Start local services
    38→uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev
    39→
    40→# Terminal 2: Apply Terraform against local endpoints
    41→terraform apply -auto-approve
    42→```
    43→
    44→### Interact with Local Services
    45→
    46→Open http://localhost:3000/_ldk/gui in your browser to see the GUI — you can watch request logs, browse DynamoDB tables, inspect S3 buckets, and interact with all your resources as you run through the steps below.
    47→
    48→In another terminal, create an order:
    49→
    50→```bash
    51→uvx --from local-web-services lws apigateway test-invoke-method \
    52→  --resource /orders \
    53→  --http-method POST \
    54→  --body '{"customerName": "Alice", "items": ["widget", "gadget"], "total": 49.99}'
    55→```
    56→
    57→Start the order processing workflow:
    58→
    59→```bash
    60→uvx --from local-web-services lws stepfunctions start-execution \
    61→  --name OrderWorkflow \
    62→  --input '{"orderId": "<ORDER_ID>", "items": ["widget", "gadget"], "total": 49.99}'
    63→```
    64→
    65→Check the workflow status:
    66→
    67→```bash
    68→uvx --from local-web-services lws stepfunctions describe-execution --execution-arn <EXECUTION_ARN>
    69→```
    70→
    71→Retrieve the order:
    72→
    73→```bash
    74→uvx --from local-web-services lws apigateway test-invoke-method \
    75→  --resource /orders/<ORDER_ID> \
    76→  --http-method GET
    77→```
    78→
    79→Store and retrieve configuration:
    80→
    81→```bash
    82→uvx --from local-web-services lws ssm put-parameter \
    83→  --name /app/table-name --value orders --type String
    84→
    85→uvx --from local-web-services lws ssm get-parameter --name /app/table-name
    86→```
    87→
    88→Store and retrieve secrets:
    89→
    90→```bash
    91→uvx --from local-web-services lws secretsmanager create-secret \
    92→  --name app/api-key --secret-string "my-secret-key"
    93→
    94→uvx --from local-web-services lws secretsmanager get-secret-value --secret-id app/api-key
    95→```
    96→
    97→Both sample projects include a full end-to-end test script (`test-orders.sh`) that runs all of these steps automatically.
    98→
    99→## Installation
   100→
   101→local-web-services requires Python 3.11+ and [uv](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/).
   102→
   103→```bash
   104→uvx --from local-web-services ldk
   105→```
   106→
   107→Or install from source:
   108→
   109→```bash
   110→git clone https://github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services.git
   111→cd local-web-services
   112→uv sync
   113→```
   114→
   115→## Quick Start (Your Own Project)
   116→
   117→### CDK Projects
   118→
   119→1. Make sure your CDK project has been synthesized:
   120→
   121→```bash
   122→cd your-cdk-project
   123→npx cdk synth
   124→```
   125→
   126→2. Start local-web-services:
   127→
   128→```bash
   129→uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev --project-dir /path/to/your-cdk-project --port 3000
   130→```
   131→
   132→`ldk` will discover your API routes, Lambda functions, DynamoDB tables, SQS queues, SNS topics, S3 buckets, Step Functions state machines, SSM parameters, and Secrets Manager secrets automatically from the CDK output.
   133→
   134→### Terraform Projects
   135→
   136→1. Initialize your Terraform project:
   137→
   138→```bash
   139→cd your-terraform-project
   140→terraform init
   141→```
   142→
   143→2. Start local-web-services:
   144→
   145→```bash
   146→uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev --project-dir /path/to/your-terraform-project
   147→```
   148→
   149→`ldk` auto-detects `.tf` files and starts all service providers in always-on mode. A `_lws_override.tf` file is generated to redirect the AWS provider to local endpoints.
   150→
   151→3. Apply your Terraform configuration:
   152→
   153→```bash
   154→terraform apply
   155→```
   156→
   157→Terraform creates resources (tables, queues, buckets, Lambda functions, API routes) against your local services. No AWS account needed.
   158→
   159→### Mode Selection
   160→
   161→`ldk dev` auto-detects your project type. To force a specific mode:
   162→
   163→```bash
   164→uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev --mode cdk        # Force CDK mode
   165→uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev --mode terraform   # Force Terraform mode
   166→```
   167→
   168→## Supported Services
   169→
   170→Each service has two dimensions of support: **IaC constructs** parsed from your project, and **API operations** emulated at runtime.
   171→
   172→### DynamoDB
   173→
   174→**CDK Constructs:**
   175→
   176→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   177→|-----------|-------------------|
   178→| `aws_dynamodb.Table` | tableName, partitionKey, sortKey, globalSecondaryIndexes |
   179→
   180→**API Operations:**
   181→
   182→| Operation | Supported |
   183→|-----------|-----------|
   184→| PutItem | Yes |
   185→| GetItem | Yes |
   186→| DeleteItem | Yes |
   187→| UpdateItem | Yes |
   188→| Query | Yes |
   189→| Scan | Yes |
   190→| BatchGetItem | Yes |
   191→| BatchWriteItem | Yes |
   192→| CreateTable | Yes |
   193→| DeleteTable | Yes |
   194→| DescribeTable | Yes |
   195→| ListTables | Yes |
   196→| TransactGetItems | Yes |
   197→| TransactWriteItems | Yes |
   198→| UpdateTable | Yes |
   199→| DescribeContinuousBackups | Yes |
   200→| UpdateTimeToLive | Yes |
   201→
   202→Backed by SQLite. Supports expression attribute names/values, filter expressions, and eventual consistency simulation.
   203→
   204→### SQS
   205→
   206→**CDK Constructs:**
   207→
   208→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   209→|-----------|-------------------|
   210→| `aws_sqs.Queue` | queueName, fifo, visibilityTimeout, contentBasedDeduplication, deadLetterQueue |
   211→
   212→**API Operations:**
   213→
   214→| Operation | Supported |
   215→|-----------|-----------|
   216→| SendMessage | Yes |
   217→| ReceiveMessage | Yes |
   218→| DeleteMessage | Yes |
   219→| CreateQueue | Yes |
   220→| DeleteQueue | Yes |
   221→| GetQueueUrl | Yes |
   222→| GetQueueAttributes | Yes |
   223→| SetQueueAttributes | Yes |
   224→| ListQueues | Yes |
   225→| PurgeQueue | Yes |
   226→| SendMessageBatch | Yes |
   227→| DeleteMessageBatch | Yes |
   228→| ChangeMessageVisibility | Yes |
   229→| ChangeMessageVisibilityBatch | Yes |
   230→| ListDeadLetterSourceQueues | Yes |
   231→
   232→Supports message attributes, long polling, and dead-letter queue wiring from RedrivePolicy.
   233→
   234→### S3
   235→
   236→**CDK Constructs:**
   237→
   238→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   239→|-----------|-------------------|
   240→| `aws_s3.Bucket` | bucketName |
   241→
   242→**API Operations:**
   243→
   244→| Operation | Supported |
   245→|-----------|-----------|
   246→| PutObject | Yes |
   247→| GetObject | Yes |
   248→| DeleteObject | Yes |
   249→| HeadObject | Yes |
   250→| ListObjectsV2 | Yes |
   251→| CreateBucket | Yes |
   252→| DeleteBucket | Yes |
   253→| HeadBucket | Yes |
   254→| ListBuckets | Yes |
   255→| CopyObject | Yes |
   256→| DeleteObjects | Yes |
   257→| PutBucketTagging | Yes |
   258→| GetBucketTagging | Yes |
   259→| DeleteBucketTagging | Yes |
   260→| GetBucketLocation | Yes |
   261→| PutBucketPolicy | Yes |
   262→| GetBucketPolicy | Yes |
   263→| PutBucketNotificationConfiguration | Yes |
   264→| GetBucketNotificationConfiguration | Yes |
   265→| CreateMultipartUpload | No |
   266→
   267→Backed by the local filesystem. Supports event notifications (ObjectCreated, ObjectRemoved), presigned URL generation, ETags, and content-type headers.
   268→
   269→### SNS
   270→
   271→**CDK Constructs:**
   272→
   273→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   274→|-----------|-------------------|
   275→| `aws_sns.Topic` | topicName |
   276→
   277→`aws_sns.Subscription` is not parsed. Subscriptions are wired at runtime via the API or auto-wired by local-web-services for Lambda/SQS targets.
   278→
   279→**API Operations:**
   280→
   281→| Operation | Supported |
   282→|-----------|-----------|
   283→| Publish | Yes |
   284→| Subscribe | Yes |
   285→| CreateTopic | Yes |
   286→| ListTopics | Yes |
   287→| ListSubscriptions | Yes |
   288→| DeleteTopic | Yes |
   289→| SetTopicAttributes | Yes |
   290→| Unsubscribe | Yes |
   291→| GetSubscriptionAttributes | Yes |
   292→| SetSubscriptionAttributes | Yes |
   293→| ConfirmSubscription | Yes |
   294→| ListSubscriptionsByTopic | Yes |
   295→
   296→Supports Lambda and SQS subscription protocols, message attributes, and fan-out to multiple subscribers.
   297→
   298→### EventBridge
   299→
   300→**CDK Constructs:**
   301→
   302→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   303→|-----------|-------------------|
   304→| `aws_events.EventBus` | eventBusName |
   305→| `aws_events.Rule` | ruleName, eventBus, eventPattern, schedule, targets |
   306→
   307→**API Operations:**
   308→
   309→| Operation | Supported |
   310→|-----------|-----------|
   311→| PutEvents | Yes |
   312→| PutRule | Yes |
   313→| PutTargets | Yes |
   314→| ListRules | Yes |
   315→| ListEventBuses | Yes |
   316→| RemoveTargets | Yes |
   317→| DeleteRule | Yes |
   318→| DescribeRule | Yes |
   319→| ListTargetsByRule | Yes |
   320→| EnableRule | Yes |
   321→| DisableRule | Yes |
   322→| TagResource | Yes |
   323→| UntagResource | Yes |
   324→| ListTagsForResource | Yes |
   325→
   326→Supports event pattern matching, schedule expressions (rate and cron), Lambda targets, and input transformations.
   327→
   328→### Step Functions
   329→
   330→**CDK Constructs:**
   331→
   332→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   333→|-----------|-------------------|
   334→| `aws_stepfunctions.StateMachine` | stateMachineName, definitionBody, stateMachineType |
   335→
   336→**API Operations:**
   337→
   338→| Operation | Supported |
   339→|-----------|-----------|
   340→| StartExecution | Yes |
   341→| StartSyncExecution | Yes |
   342→| DescribeExecution | Yes |
   343→| ListExecutions | Yes |
   344→| ListStateMachines | Yes |
   345→| CreateStateMachine | Yes |
   346→| StopExecution | Yes |
   347→| GetExecutionHistory | Yes |
   348→| UpdateStateMachine | Yes |
   349→
   350→State types: Task, Pass, Choice, Wait, Succeed, Fail, Parallel, Map. Supports JSONPath (InputPath, OutputPath, ResultPath), error handling (Retry, Catch), and Standard & Express workflows.
   351→
   352→### Cognito
   353→
   354→**CDK Constructs:**
   355→
   356→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   357→|-----------|-------------------|
   358→| `aws_cognito.UserPool` | userPoolName, lambdaTriggers (preAuthentication, postConfirmation), passwordPolicy |
   359→| `aws_cognito.UserPoolClient` | userPool |
   360→
   361→**API Operations:**
   362→
   363→| Operation | Supported |
   364→|-----------|-----------|
   365→| SignUp | Yes |
   366→| ConfirmSignUp | Yes |
   367→| InitiateAuth | Yes (USER_PASSWORD_AUTH) |
   368→| JWKS endpoint | Yes |
   369→| CreateUserPoolClient | Yes |
   370→| DeleteUserPoolClient | Yes |
   371→| DescribeUserPoolClient | Yes |
   372→| ListUserPoolClients | Yes |
   373→| AdminCreateUser | Yes |
   374→| AdminDeleteUser | Yes |
   375→| AdminGetUser | Yes |
   376→| UpdateUserPool | Yes |
   377→| ListUsers | Yes |
   378→| ForgotPassword | No |
   379→| ChangePassword | No |
   380→| GlobalSignOut | No |
   381→
   382→Backed by SQLite. Supports JWT token generation (ID, access, refresh), user attributes, and password hashing.
   383→
   384→### Lambda
   385→
   386→**CDK Constructs:**
   387→
   388→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   389→|-----------|-------------------|
   390→| `aws_lambda.Function` | handler, runtime, code, timeout, memorySize, environment |
   391→
   392→**Management API (Terraform mode):**
   393→
   394→| Operation | Supported |
   395→|-----------|-----------|
   396→| CreateFunction | Yes |
   397→| GetFunction | Yes |
   398→| DeleteFunction | Yes |
   399→| ListFunctions | Yes |
   400→| Invoke | Yes |
   401→| UpdateFunctionConfiguration | Yes |
   402→| UpdateFunctionCode | Yes |
   403→| TagResource | Yes |
   404→| UntagResource | Yes |
   405→| ListEventSourceMappings | Yes |
   406→
   407→Runs functions locally using Python or Node.js runtimes. Supports timeout enforcement, realistic context objects, and environment variable injection. In CDK mode, functions are discovered from the cloud assembly. In Terraform mode, functions are created dynamically via the management API.
   408→
   409→### API Gateway
   410→
   411→**CDK Constructs:**
   412→
   413→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   414→|-----------|-------------------|
   415→| `aws_apigateway.RestApi` | routes, methods, integrations |
   416→| `aws_apigatewayv2.HttpApi` | routes, integrations |
   417→
   418→**REST API (V1) Management:**
   419→
   420→CreateRestApi, GetRestApi, DeleteRestApi, CreateResource, PutMethod, PutIntegration, CreateDeployment, CreateStage.
   421→
   422→**HTTP API (V2) Management:**
   423→
   424→CreateApi, GetApi, DeleteApi, CreateRoute, CreateIntegration, CreateStage, ListRoutes, ListIntegrations, ListStages.
   425→
   426→Supports both REST API (V1) and HTTP API (V2) with Lambda proxy integration. Routes requests to local Lambda functions with path parameters, query parameters, and request/response mapping.
   427→
   428→### ECS
   429→
   430→**CDK Constructs:**
   431→
   432→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   433→|-----------|-------------------|
   434→| `aws_ecs.TaskDefinition` | containerDefinitions |
   435→| `aws_ecs.FargateService` / `aws_ecs.Ec2Service` | taskDefinition |
   436→| `aws_elasticloadbalancingv2.ApplicationListenerRule` | conditions, actions |
   437→
   438→Runs services as local subprocesses. Supports health checking, service discovery, file watching with auto-restart, and port mapping. Supports local command overrides via `ldk.local_command` metadata. CDK mode only.
   439→
   440→### IAM & STS
   441→
   442→Stub APIs that return AWS-compatible responses for Terraform compatibility. IAM role and policy operations are accepted and stored in memory (CreateRole, GetRole, DeleteRole, CreatePolicy, GetPolicy, DeletePolicy, AttachRolePolicy, DetachRolePolicy, CreatePolicyVersion, ListRoles, ListPolicies). STS returns dummy credentials and caller identity (GetCallerIdentity, AssumeRole).
   443→
   444→### SSM Parameter Store
   445→
   446→**CDK Constructs:**
   447→
   448→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   449→|-----------|-------------------|
   450→| `aws_ssm.StringParameter` | Name, Type, Value, Description |
   451→
   452→**API Operations:**
   453→
   454→| Operation | Supported |
   455→|-----------|-----------|
   456→| PutParameter | Yes |
   457→| GetParameter | Yes |
   458→| GetParameters | Yes |
   459→| GetParametersByPath | Yes |
   460→| DeleteParameter | Yes |
   461→| DeleteParameters | Yes |
   462→| DescribeParameters | Yes |
   463→| AddTagsToResource | Yes |
   464→| RemoveTagsFromResource | Yes |
   465→| ListTagsForResource | Yes |
   466→
   467→In-memory parameter store supporting String, StringList, and SecureString types. Supports versioning (auto-incremented on overwrite), descriptions, and tags. In CDK mode, parameters defined in the CloudFormation template are pre-seeded on startup.
   468→
   469→### Secrets Manager
   470→
   471→**CDK Constructs:**
   472→
   473→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   474→|-----------|-------------------|
   475→| `aws_secretsmanager.Secret` | Name, Description, SecretString, GenerateSecretString |
   476→
   477→**API Operations:**
   478→
   479→| Operation | Supported |
   480→|-----------|-----------|
   481→| CreateSecret | Yes |
   482→| GetSecretValue | Yes |
   483→| PutSecretValue | Yes |
   484→| UpdateSecret | Yes |
   485→| DeleteSecret | Yes |
   486→| DescribeSecret | Yes |
   487→| ListSecrets | Yes |
   488→| RestoreSecret | Yes |
   489→| TagResource | Yes |
   490→| UntagResource | Yes |
   491→| ListSecretVersionIds | Yes |
   492→
   493→In-memory secret store supporting version staging (AWSCURRENT/AWSPREVIOUS), soft delete with optional recovery, and tags. In CDK mode, secrets defined in the CloudFormation template are pre-seeded on startup.
   494→
   495→## Development
   496→
   497→All development tasks are available through `make`:
   498→
   499→```bash
   500→make install       # Install dependencies
   501→make test          # Run test suite
   502→make lint          # Run linter
   503→make format        # Auto-format code
   504→make check         # Run all checks (lint, format, complexity, tests)
   505→```
   506→
   507→Run `make` with no arguments to see all available targets.
   508→
   509→## Documentation
   510→
   511→Visit [https://local-web-services.github.io/www/](https://local-web-services.github.io/www/) for full documentation.
   512→
   513→## Contributing
   514→
   515→See [CONTRIBUTING.md](CONTRIBUTING.md) for guidelines on how to contribute.
   516→
   517→## License
   518→
   519→This project is licensed under the MIT License. See [LICENSE](LICENSE) for details.
   520→

1→# ldk-sample-project
     2→
     3→A serverless order processing system built with AWS CDK and designed for local development with [LDK (Local Development Kit)](https://github.com/local-development-kit/ldk).
     4→
     5→## Architecture
     6→
     7→The application implements an event-driven order processing workflow using the following AWS services:
     8→
     9→- **API Gateway (HTTP)** - REST endpoints for creating and retrieving orders
    10→- **Lambda** - Four Node.js 20.x functions handling order lifecycle
    11→- **DynamoDB** - Order persistence (`Orders` table)
    12→- **SQS** - Asynchronous order processing queue with dead letter queue
    13→- **Step Functions** - `OrderWorkflow` state machine orchestrating processing, receipt generation, and notification
    14→- **S3** - Receipt storage
    15→- **SNS** - Order status notifications
    16→- **SSM Parameter Store** - Application configuration parameters
    17→- **Secrets Manager** - Secure storage for API keys and credentials
    18→
    19→### Request Flow
    20→
    21→```
    22→POST /orders
    23→  -> CreateOrderFunction
    24→       -> DynamoDB (store order)
    25→       -> SQS (enqueue for processing)
    26→
    27→Step Functions (OrderWorkflow):
    28→  ProcessOrder -> GenerateReceipt -> NotifyCustomer -> OrderComplete
    29→
    30→GET /orders/{id}
    31→  -> GetOrderFunction
    32→       -> DynamoDB (retrieve order)
    33→```
    34→
    35→## Project Structure
    36→
    37→```
    38→ldk-sample-project/
    39→├── bin/app.ts                      # CDK app entry point
    40→├── lib/order-processing-stack.ts   # CDK stack definition
    41→├── lambda/
    42→│   ├── create-order/index.js       # Create order, store in DynamoDB, enqueue to SQS
    43→│   ├── get-order/index.js          # Retrieve order from DynamoDB
    44→│   ├── process-order/index.js      # Process order, publish SNS notification
    45→│   └── generate-receipt/index.js   # Generate receipt, store in S3
    46→├── test-orders.sh                  # End-to-end test script
    47→├── cdk.json                        # CDK configuration
    48→└── package.json                    # Dependencies
    49→```
    50→
    51→## Prerequisites
    52→
    53→- [Node.js](https://nodejs.org/) >= 20.x
    54→- [AWS CDK](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cdk/) >= 2.170.0
    55→- [LDK](https://github.com/local-development-kit/ldk) for local development
    56→
    57→## Setup
    58→
    59→```bash
    60→npm install
    61→npx cdk synth
    62→```
    63→
    64→## Local Development
    65→
    66→Start the local development environment with LDK:
    67→
    68→```bash
    69→ldk dev
    70→```
    71→
    72→This starts all services locally (API Gateway, DynamoDB, SQS, S3, SNS, Step Functions, SSM Parameter Store, Secrets Manager) and watches for file changes.
    73→
    74→### Available Local Resources
    75→
    76→| Type          | Name               | Details                         |
    77→|---------------|--------------------|---------------------------------|
    78→| API Route     | POST /orders       | Create a new order              |
    79→| API Route     | GET /orders/{id}   | Retrieve an order               |
    80→| Table         | Orders             | Order data (partition key: orderId) |
    81→| Queue         | order-queue        | Order processing queue          |
    82→| Queue         | order-dlq          | Dead letter queue               |
    83→| Bucket        | ReceiptsBucket     | Receipt storage                 |
    84→| Topic         | order-notifications         | Order status notifications        |
    85→| Parameter     | /orders/config/max-items    | Max items per order config        |
    86→| Secret        | orders/notification-api-key | Notification API key              |
    87→| State Machine | OrderWorkflow               | Order processing workflow         |
    88→
    89→## Running Tests
    90→
    91→Run the end-to-end test script while `ldk dev` is running:
    92→
    93→```bash
    94→bash test-orders.sh
    95→```
    96→
    97→This script:
    98→1. Creates an order via POST /orders
    99→2. Starts the OrderWorkflow state machine
   100→3. Polls until the workflow completes
   101→4. Retrieves the order via GET /orders/{id}
   102→
   103→### Example Output
   104→
   105→```
   106→=== Creating order ===
   107→Order ID: dbdbbfe3-a4d8-408d-ad55-78b1de2e3873
   108→
   109→=== Starting OrderWorkflow ===
   110→
   111→=== Polling for workflow completion ===
   112→  Attempt 1: RUNNING
   113→  Attempt 2: SUCCEEDED
   114→
   115→Workflow output:
   116→{
   117→  "processed": 1,
   118→  "results": [
   119→    {
   120→      "orderId": "dbdbbfe3-a4d8-408d-ad55-78b1de2e3873",
   121→      "status": "PROCESSED"
   122→    }
   123→  ]
   124→}
   125→
   126→=== Getting order ===
   127→{
   128→  "orderId": "dbdbbfe3-a4d8-408d-ad55-78b1de2e3873",
   129→  "customerName": "Alice",
   130→  "items": ["widget", "gadget"],
   131→  "total": 49.99,
   132→  "createdAt": "2026-02-08T16:41:20.649Z"
   133→}
   134→```
   135→
   136→## Deploying to AWS
   137→
   138→```bash
   139→npx cdk deploy
   140→```
   141→
   142→## License
   143→
   144→MIT
   145→

1→# lws-sample-project-terraform
     2→
     3→A serverless order processing system built with [Terraform](https://www.terraform.io/) / [OpenTofu](https://opentofu.org/) and designed for local development with [Local Web Services](https://github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services).
     4→
     5→## Architecture
     6→
     7→The application implements an event-driven order processing workflow using the following AWS services:
     8→
     9→- **API Gateway (HTTP)** - REST endpoints for creating and retrieving orders
    10→- **Lambda** - Four Node.js 20.x functions handling order lifecycle
    11→- **DynamoDB** - Order persistence (`Orders` table)
    12→- **SQS** - Asynchronous order processing queue with dead letter queue
    13→- **Step Functions** - `OrderWorkflow` state machine orchestrating processing, receipt generation, and notification
    14→- **S3** - Receipt storage
    15→- **SNS** - Order status notifications
    16→- **SSM Parameter Store** - Application configuration parameters
    17→- **Secrets Manager** - Secure storage for API keys and credentials
    18→
    19→### Request Flow
    20→
    21→```
    22→POST /orders
    23→  -> CreateOrderFunction
    24→       -> DynamoDB (store order)
    25→       -> SQS (enqueue for processing)
    26→
    27→Step Functions (OrderWorkflow):
    28→  ValidateOrder -> ProcessPayment -> GenerateReceipt -> NotifyCustomer -> OrderComplete
    29→
    30→GET /orders/{id}
    31→  -> GetOrderFunction
    32→       -> DynamoDB (retrieve order)
    33→```
    34→
    35→## Project Structure
    36→
    37→```
    38→lws-sample-project-terraform/
    39→├── main.tf                            # Provider configuration
    40→├── variables.tf                       # Input variables
    41→├── outputs.tf                         # Stack outputs
    42→├── dynamodb.tf                        # DynamoDB table
    43→├── sqs.tf                             # SQS queues
    44→├── s3.tf                              # S3 bucket
    45→├── sns.tf                             # SNS topic
    46→├── ssm.tf                             # SSM Parameter Store parameters
    47→├── secretsmanager.tf                  # Secrets Manager secrets
    48→├── iam.tf                             # IAM roles and policies
    49→├── lambda.tf                          # Lambda functions
    50→├── apigateway.tf                      # HTTP API Gateway
    51→├── stepfunctions.tf                   # Step Functions state machine
    52→├── lambda/
    53→│   ├── create-order/index.js          # Create order, store in DynamoDB, enqueue to SQS
    54→│   ├── get-order/index.js             # Retrieve order from DynamoDB
    55→│   ├── process-order/index.js         # Process order, publish SNS notification
    56→│   └── generate-receipt/index.js      # Generate receipt, store in S3
    57→└── test-orders.sh                     # End-to-end test script
    58→```
    59→
    60→## Prerequisites
    61→
    62→- [uv](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/getting-started/installation/) (for running local-web-services)
    63→- [Terraform](https://www.terraform.io/) >= 1.0 or [OpenTofu](https://opentofu.org/) >= 1.6
    64→- Node.js 18+
    65→
    66→## Setup
    67→
    68→Install Lambda function dependencies:
    69→
    70→```bash
    71→cd lambda/create-order && npm install && cd ../..
    72→cd lambda/get-order && npm install && cd ../..
    73→cd lambda/process-order && npm install && cd ../..
    74→cd lambda/generate-receipt && npm install && cd ../..
    75→```
    76→
    77→Initialize Terraform (or OpenTofu):
    78→
    79→```bash
    80→terraform init
    81→# or
    82→tofu init
    83→```
    84→
    85→## Local Development
    86→
    87→### How It Works
    88→
    89→When you run `ldk dev` in this directory, it:
    90→
    91→1. **Detects** the `.tf` files and enters Terraform mode automatically
    92→2. **Starts** all AWS service providers locally (DynamoDB, SQS, S3, SNS, Step Functions, API Gateway, Lambda, IAM, STS, SSM, Secrets Manager)
    93→3. **Generates** a `_lws_override.tf` file that redirects all AWS provider endpoints to your local services (this file is auto-added to `.gitignore`)
    94→4. **Watches** for file changes and reloads automatically
    95→
    96→You then run `terraform apply` (or `tofu apply`) against these local endpoints — no AWS account needed.
    97→
    98→### Start the local environment
    99→
   100→```bash
   101→# Terminal 1: Start local services
   102→uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev
   103→```
   104→
   105→### Apply Terraform / OpenTofu
   106→
   107→```bash
   108→# Terminal 2: Apply against local endpoints
   109→terraform apply -auto-approve
   110→# or
   111→tofu apply -auto-approve
   112→```
   113→
   114→This creates all resources (tables, queues, Lambda functions, API routes, etc.) against your local services.
   115→
   116→### Available Local Resources
   117→
   118→| Type          | Name               | Details                         |
   119→|---------------|--------------------|---------------------------------|
   120→| API Route     | POST /orders       | Create a new order              |
   121→| API Route     | GET /orders/{id}   | Retrieve an order               |
   122→| Table         | Orders             | Order data (partition key: orderId) |
   123→| Queue         | order-queue        | Order processing queue          |
   124→| Queue         | order-dlq          | Dead letter queue               |
   125→| Bucket        | ReceiptsBucket     | Receipt storage                 |
   126→| Topic         | order-notifications         | Order status notifications        |
   127→| Parameter     | /orders/config/max-items    | Max items per order config        |
   128→| Secret        | orders/notification-api-key | Notification API key              |
   129→| State Machine | OrderWorkflow               | Order processing workflow         |
   130→
   131→## Running Tests
   132→
   133→Run the end-to-end test script while `ldk dev` is running and after `terraform apply` / `tofu apply`:
   134→
   135→```bash
   136→bash test-orders.sh
   137→```
   138→
   139→This script:
   140→1. Creates an order via POST /orders
   141→2. Starts the OrderWorkflow state machine
   142→3. Polls until the workflow completes
   143→4. Retrieves the order via GET /orders/{id}
   144→
   145→### Example Output
   146→
   147→```
   148→=== Creating order ===
   149→Order ID: dbdbbfe3-a4d8-408d-ad55-78b1de2e3873
   150→
   151→=== Starting OrderWorkflow ===
   152→
   153→=== Polling for workflow completion ===
   154→  Attempt 1: RUNNING
   155→  Attempt 2: SUCCEEDED
   156→
   157→Workflow output:
   158→{
   159→  "processed": 1,
   160→  "results": [
   161→    {
   162→      "orderId": "dbdbbfe3-a4d8-408d-ad55-78b1de2e3873",
   163→      "status": "PROCESSED"
   164→    }
   165→  ]
   166→}
   167→
   168→=== Getting order ===
   169→{
   170→  "orderId": "dbdbbfe3-a4d8-408d-ad55-78b1de2e3873",
   171→  "customerName": "Alice",
   172→  "items": ["widget", "gadget"],
   173→  "total": 49.99,
   174→  "createdAt": "2026-02-08T16:41:20.649Z"
   175→}
   176→```
   177→
   178→## Deploying to AWS
   179→
   180→To deploy to real AWS (instead of local), remove the `_lws_override.tf` file (if present) and run:
   181→
   182→```bash
   183→terraform apply
   184→# or
   185→tofu apply
   186→```
   187→
   188→## License
   189→
   190→MIT
   191→

1→# Local Web Services - Documentation Site
     2→
     3→Documentation site for the [Local Web Services](https://github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services) project.
     4→
     5→**Live site:** https://local-web-services.github.io/www/
     6→
     7→## About
     8→
     9→Local Web Services provides two complementary CLI tools for local AWS CDK development:
    10→
    11→- **ldk** - Runs your AWS CDK applications locally as a development server
    12→- **lws** - AWS CLI-style commands for interacting with local services
    13→
    14→## Local preview
    15→
    16→Open `index.html` in a browser.
    17→
    18→## Deployment
    19→
    20→The site deploys automatically on push to `main` via the GitHub Actions workflow in `.github/workflows/deploy.yml`. To enable it:
    21→
    22→1. Go to the repository **Settings > Pages**
    23→2. Under **Build and deployment**, set the source to **GitHub Actions**
    24→

content.content:
1→# local-web-services Architecture
     2→
     3→local-web-services is a local AWS emulator for CDK applications. It parses synthesized CloudFormation templates from `cdk.out/` and runs local emulations of AWS services so developers can build and test without deploying to AWS. It provides two CLIs: `ldk` (the server) and `lws` (an AWS CLI-compatible client).
     4→
     5→## High-Level Overview
     6→
     7→```
     8→                          ldk dev
     9→                            |
    10→                     +------v------+
    11→                     |    CLI      |  (Typer)
    12→                     +------+------+
    13→                            |
    14→              +-------------+-------------+
    15→              |                           |
    16→      +-------v-------+          +-------v-------+
    17→      | Config Loader |          |  CDK Synth    |
    18→      +-------+-------+          +-------+-------+
    19→              |                           |
    20→              +-------------+-------------+
    21→                            |
    22→                    +-------v-------+
    23→                    |   Assembly    |  Parses cdk.out/ into AppModel
    24→                    |   Parser      |
    25→                    +-------+-------+
    26→                            |
    27→                    +-------v-------+
    28→                    |  Graph        |  Builds dependency graph,
    29→                    |  Builder      |  topological sort
    30→                    +-------+-------+
    31→                            |
    32→                    +-------v-------+
    33→                    |  Orchestrator |  Starts/stops providers
    34→                    +-------+-------+   in dependency order
    35→                            |
    36→          +---------+-------+-------+---------+
    37→          |         |       |       |         |
    38→       +--v--+   +--v--+ +-v-+  +--v--+  +---v---+
    39→       | API |   | Lam |  |Dyn|  | SQS |  | more  |
    40→       | GW  |   | bda |  |amo|  |     |  |  ...  |
    41→       +-----+   +-----+  +---+  +-----+  +-------+
    42→          :          :       :       :
    43→          :   Each provider runs as a FastAPI app
    44→          :   on its own port (base, base+1, ...)
    45→          :
    46→       +--+----------------------------------------------+
    47→       |  lws CLI (client)                               |
    48→       |  AWS CLI-style commands that talk to providers   |
    49→       |  via /_ldk/ management API + wire protocols      |
    50→       +-------------------------------------------------+
    51→```
    52→
    53→## Directory Structure
    54→
    55→```
    56→src/lws/
    57→  cli/              CLI commands (Typer)
    58→    main.py          ldk dev, ldk invoke, ldk reset (server)
    59→    lws.py           lws CLI entry point (client)
    60→    services/        Per-service lws sub-commands
    61→      client.py      LwsClient: discovery + wire protocol helpers
    62→      dynamodb.py    lws dynamodb put-item, get-item, scan, query, ...
    63→      sqs.py         lws sqs send-message, receive-message, ...
    64→      s3.py          lws s3api put-object, get-object, ...
    65→      sns.py         lws sns publish, list-topics, ...
    66→      events.py      lws events put-events, ...
    67→      stepfunctions  lws stepfunctions start-execution, ...
    68→      cognito.py     lws cognito-idp sign-up, admin-get-user, ...
    69→      apigateway.py  lws apigateway get-rest-apis, ...
    70→
    71→  parser/            CDK CloudFormation parsing
    72→    assembly.py      Top-level orchestrator, produces AppModel
    73→    template_parser  Extracts resources from CloudFormation JSON
    74→    tree_parser.py   Parses CDK tree.json
    75→    asset_parser.py  Resolves Lambda code asset paths
    76→    ref_resolver.py  Resolves Ref, GetAtt, Sub intrinsics
    77→
    78→  providers/         AWS service emulations
    79→    apigateway/      FastAPI-based HTTP gateway
    80→    lambda_runtime/  Python and Node.js Lambda execution
    81→    dynamodb/        SQLite-backed key-value store
    82→    sqs/             In-memory queue
    83→    s3/              Filesystem-backed object store
    84→    sns/             Pub/sub messaging
    85→    eventbridge/     Event pattern matching and routing
    86→    stepfunctions/   Amazon States Language interpreter
    87→    ecs/             Container process management
    88→    cognito/         User pool and JWT token generation
    89→
    90→  interfaces/        Abstract base classes
    91→    provider.py      Provider lifecycle (start/stop/health_check)
    92→    compute.py       ICompute for Lambda execution
    93→    key_value_store  IKeyValueStore for DynamoDB
    94→    queue.py         IQueue for SQS
    95→    object_store.py  IObjectStore for S3
    96→    event_bus.py     IEventBus for EventBridge
    97→    state_machine.py IStateMachine for Step Functions
    98→
    99→  runtime/           Lifecycle and orchestration
   100→    orchestrator.py  Starts/stops providers in dependency order
   101→    env_builder.py   Builds Lambda environment variables
   102→    sdk_env.py       Redirects AWS SDKs to local ports
   103→    watcher.py       File watching for hot reload
   104→    synth.py         CDK synth execution wrapper
   105→
   106→  graph/             Dependency graph
   107→    builder.py       Directed graph with topological sort
   108→
   109→  config/            Configuration
   110→    loader.py        Loads ldk.config.py or ldk.yaml
   111→
   112→  api/               Management API
   113→    management.py    /_ldk/ endpoints (invoke, status, reset)
   114→    gui.py           Web dashboard
   115→
   116→  logging/           Observability
   117→    logger.py        Structured logger with WebSocket streaming
   118→    middleware.py    Request/response logging middleware
   119→    tracer.py        Request tracing
   120→
   121→  validation/        Input validation
   122→    engine.py        Validation orchestration
   123→    schema_validator Event payload validation
   124→    permission_validator  IAM-like permission checks
   125→```
   126→
   127→## Core Concepts
   128→
   129→### Provider
   130→
   131→Every AWS service emulator implements the `Provider` abstract base class (`interfaces/provider.py`):
   132→
   133→```python
   134→class Provider(ABC):
   135→    @property
   136→    def name(self) -> str: ...
   137→    async def start(self) -> None: ...
   138→    async def stop(self) -> None: ...
   139→    async def health_check(self) -> bool: ...
   140→```
   141→
   142→Providers that support persistence also implement `flush()` which the orchestrator calls before shutdown.
   143→
   144→### AppModel
   145→
   146→The parser layer produces an `AppModel` dataclass (`parser/assembly.py`) containing all discovered infrastructure: Lambda functions, DynamoDB tables, API routes, SQS queues, SNS topics, S3 buckets, EventBridge buses, Step Functions state machines, ECS services, and Cognito user pools. This is the single data structure the rest of the system consumes.
   147→
   148→### AppGraph
   149→
   150→The graph builder (`graph/builder.py`) converts the `AppModel` into a directed graph of `Node` and `Edge` objects. Nodes have types (`NodeType` enum: `LAMBDA_FUNCTION`, `DYNAMODB_TABLE`, `API_GATEWAY`, etc.) and edges have types (`EdgeType` enum: `TRIGGER`, `DATA_DEPENDENCY`, `PERMISSION`, `EVENT_SOURCE`). Topological sort determines provider startup order.
   151→
   152→### Orchestrator
   153→
   154→The orchestrator (`runtime/orchestrator.py`) owns the full provider lifecycle:
   155→
   156→1. Starts providers in topological order (dependencies first)
   157→2. Health-checks each provider after start
   158→3. Installs signal handlers for graceful shutdown (SIGINT/SIGTERM)
   159→4. On shutdown: flushes state, then stops providers in reverse order
   160→5. A second signal forces immediate exit
   161→
   162→### lws CLI
   163→
   164→The `lws` command (`cli/lws.py`) is a separate CLI that acts as an AWS CLI-compatible client for a running `ldk dev` instance. Where `ldk dev` starts the server, `lws` talks to it.
   165→
   166→`lws` uses service discovery via the `/_ldk/resources` management endpoint to find each provider's port, then speaks the provider's wire protocol directly:
   167→
   168→- **JSON target dispatch** (`X-Amz-Target` header) for DynamoDB, SQS, SNS, Step Functions, EventBridge, Cognito
   169→- **Form-encoded** requests for SQS (query-style API)
   170→- **REST-style** requests for S3 and API Gateway
   171→
   172→The shared `LwsClient` (`cli/services/client.py`) handles discovery and provides helpers for each protocol. Individual service modules (`cli/services/dynamodb.py`, `cli/services/sqs.py`, etc.) expose AWS CLI-style commands:
   173→
   174→```
   175→lws status                                         # provider health + ports
   176→lws dynamodb put-item --table-name T --item '{}'   # DynamoDB operations
   177→lws sqs send-message --queue-name Q --message-body '...'
   178→lws s3api put-object --bucket B --key K --body '...'
   179→lws stepfunctions start-execution --state-machine-arn ...
   180→lws cognito-idp sign-up --user-pool-id ... --username ...
   181→lws sns publish --topic-arn ... --message '...'
   182→lws events put-events --entries '[...]'
   183→lws apigateway get-rest-apis
   184→```
   185→
   186→```
   187→lws dynamodb scan --table-name Orders
   188→     |
   189→     v
   190→LwsClient.discover()  -->  GET /_ldk/resources  -->  {dynamodb: {port: 3001}}
   191→     |
   192→     v
   193→LwsClient.json_target_request("dynamodb", "DynamoDB_20120810.Scan", {...})
   194→     |
   195→     v
   196→POST http://localhost:3001/   (X-Amz-Target: DynamoDB_20120810.Scan)
   197→     |
   198→     v
   199→SqliteDynamoProvider handles request
   200→```
   201→
   202→## Request Flow
   203→
   204→```
   205→HTTP request
   206→     |
   207→     v
   208→API Gateway Provider (port 3000)
   209→     |
   210→     +---> RequestLoggingMiddleware (captures method, path, duration)
   211→     |
   212→     +---> Route matching (from parsed CDK routes)
   213→     |
   214→     v
   215→Lambda Compute (PythonCompute or NodeJsCompute)
   216→     |
   217→     +---> Builds Lambda event from HTTP request
   218→     +---> Resolves handler function
   219→     +---> Executes handler with SDK env vars pointing to local ports
   220→     |
   221→     v
   222→Handler may call other local services via AWS SDK:
   223→     DynamoDB  ->  localhost:{base+1}  (SQLite)
   224→     SQS       ->  localhost:{base+2}  (in-memory)
   225→     S3        ->  localhost:{base+3}  (filesystem)
   226→     SNS       ->  localhost:{base+4}  (in-memory)
   227→     EventBridge -> localhost:{base+5}
   228→     Step Fn   ->  localhost:{base+6}
   229→     Cognito   ->  localhost:{base+7}
   230→```
   231→
   232→## Port Allocation
   233→
   234→Each service binds to a deterministic port offset from the configured base port (default 3000):
   235→
   236→| Offset | Service        | Storage Backend  |
   237→|--------|----------------|------------------|
   238→| +0     | API Gateway    | -                |
   239→| +1     | DynamoDB       | SQLite           |
   240→| +2     | SQS            | In-memory        |
   241→| +3     | S3             | Filesystem       |
   242→| +4     | SNS            | In-memory        |
   243→| +5     | EventBridge    | In-memory        |
   244→| +6     | Step Functions | In-memory        |
   245→| +7     | Cognito        | SQLite           |
   246→
   247→The management API (`/_ldk/`) is served on the same port as API Gateway.
   248→
   249→## SDK Redirection
   250→
   251→`runtime/sdk_env.py` builds environment variables (`AWS_ENDPOINT_URL_DYNAMODB`, etc.) that the AWS SDKs respect. When Lambda handlers make SDK calls, traffic is automatically routed to the local providers instead of real AWS.
   252→
   253→## Configuration
   254→
   255→Configuration is resolved in priority order (highest wins):
   256→
   257→1. CLI arguments (`--port`, `--log-level`, `--no-persist`)
   258→2. Environment variables (`LDK_PORT`, `LDK_LOG_LEVEL`, etc.)
   259→3. Config file (`ldk.config.py` or `ldk.yaml`)
   260→4. Defaults
   261→
   262→Key options: `port`, `persist`, `data_dir`, `log_level`, `cdk_out_dir`, `watch_include`, `watch_exclude`.
   263→
   264→## Startup Sequence
   265→
   266→1. **CLI** parses arguments and loads configuration
   267→2. **Config loader** merges CLI args, env vars, and config file
   268→3. **CDK synth** runs if `cdk.out/` is missing or `--force-synth` is set
   269→4. **Assembly parser** reads CloudFormation templates into `AppModel`
   270→5. **Graph builder** creates dependency graph and topological order
   271→6. **Provider creation** instantiates all service providers
   272→7. **SDK env setup** configures AWS endpoint redirection
   273→8. **Orchestrator** starts providers in dependency order, health-checks each
   274→9. **File watcher** monitors source files for hot reload
   275→10. **Management API** exposes `/_ldk/` endpoints and web GUI
   276→
   277→## Testing
   278→
   279→```
   280→tests/
   281→  unit/           Fast, isolated tests per module
   282→  integration/    End-to-end tests with multiple services
   283→  architecture/   Architecture decision record tests
   284→  fixtures/       Sample CDK applications for testing
   285→```
   286→
   287→Run with `make test` or `uv run pytest`.
   288→
   289→## Key Dependencies
   290→
   291→- **FastAPI** + **Uvicorn** - HTTP serving for all providers
   292→- **Typer** - CLI framework
   293→- **aiosqlite** - Async SQLite for DynamoDB and Cognito persistence
   294→- **httpx** - Async HTTP client for service-to-service calls
   295→- **PyJWT** - JWT generation for Cognito
   296→- **watchdog** - Filesystem monitoring for hot reload
   297→- **Rich** - Terminal output formatting
   298→- **croniter** - Cron expression parsing for EventBridge schedules
   299→
   300→## Design Patterns
   301→
   302→- **Provider pattern** - Uniform lifecycle interface for all service emulators
   303→- **Adapter pattern** - Each provider adapts AWS APIs to local storage (e.g., DynamoDB API to SQLite)
   304→- **Strategy pattern** - Multiple compute backends (PythonCompute, NodeJsCompute)
   305→- **Graph-based orchestration** - Dependency graph with topological sort for startup ordering
   306→- **Dependency injection** - Compute providers injected into API Gateway, SNS, EventBridge
   307→- **Middleware pipeline** - RequestLoggingMiddleware wraps all service endpoints
   308→

content.content:
1→# Contributing to LDK
     2→
     3→Thanks for your interest in contributing to LDK. This guide explains how to get involved.
     4→
     5→## Reporting Bugs
     6→
     7→Please open a [GitHub issue](https://github.com/local-development-kit/ldk/issues) and include:
     8→
     9→- **Steps to reproduce** -- the minimal commands or configuration needed to trigger the bug
    10→- **Expected behaviour** -- what you expected to happen
    11→- **Actual behaviour** -- what actually happened, including any error messages or logs
    12→
    13→## Feature Requests
    14→
    15→If you have an idea for a new feature, the preferred approach is to raise it as an [OpenSpec](https://github.com/Fission-AI/OpenSpec/) change proposal and submit it as a pull request. An OpenSpec proposal includes a description of the change, the requirements, and scenarios that define the expected behaviour. This keeps changes well-documented and reviewable before implementation begins.
    16→
    17→If you'd rather get feedback before writing a proposal, open a [GitHub issue](https://github.com/local-development-kit/ldk/issues) describing the feature. This helps reduce duplicated effort and gives you advice on how best to get the change added.
    18→
    19→## Development Setup
    20→
    21→1. Clone the repository:
    22→
    23→```bash
    24→git clone https://github.com/local-development-kit/ldk.git
    25→cd ldk
    26→```
    27→
    28→2. Install dependencies:
    29→
    30→```bash
    31→make install
    32→```
    33→
    34→3. Run the tests:
    35→
    36→```bash
    37→make test
    38→```
    39→
    40→4. Run all checks (lint, format, complexity, tests):
    41→
    42→```bash
    43→make check
    44→```
    45→
    46→## Submitting a Pull Request
    47→
    48→1. Fork the repository and create a branch from `main`.
    49→2. Make your changes and add tests where appropriate.
    50→3. Ensure all tests pass and linting is clean.
    51→4. Open a pull request with a clear description of what you changed and why.
    52→
    53→## License
    54→
    55→By contributing to LDK, you agree that your contributions will be licensed under the [MIT License](LICENSE).
    56→

- Contains: Documentation site overview for local-web-services, description of ldk and lws CLI tools, deployment information via GitHub Actions

### Additional Important Documentation Files:

**5. ARCHITECTURE.md** (main repo)
- Path: `/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services/ARCHITECTURE.md`
- Key content: High-level overview diagrams, directory structure, core concepts (Provider, AppModel, AppGraph, Orchestrator), request flow, port allocation scheme, SDK redirection mechanism, configuration priority, startup sequence, testing info, dependencies, and design patterns
- **Mentions Lambda setup extensively** with detailed architecture for Lambda execution (Python and Node.js runtimes)

**6. CONTRIBUTING.md** (main repo and sample projects)
- Paths: 
  - `/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services/CONTRIBUTING.md`
  - `/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/sample-project/CONTRIBUTING.md`
  - `/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/sample-project-terraform/CONTRIBUTING.md`

**7. Other Documentation Files:**

The **README.md (root)** and **ARCHITECTURE.md** are the primary files mentioning:
