content.content:
1→# local-web-services
     2→
     3→Run your AWS CDK and Terraform applications locally. local-web-services reads your CDK cloud assembly or Terraform configuration and spins up local emulations of API Gateway, Lambda, DynamoDB, SQS, SNS, S3, Step Functions, Cognito, EventBridge, SSM Parameter Store, Secrets Manager, and more — so you can develop and test without deploying to AWS.
     4→
     5→## Try It Out
     6→
     7→### CDK Sample Project
     8→
     9→Clone the [CDK sample project](https://github.com/local-web-services/sample-project) — a serverless order processing system with API Gateway, Lambda, DynamoDB, SQS, S3, SNS, and Step Functions:
    10→
    11→```bash
    12→git clone https://github.com/local-web-services/sample-project.git
    13→cd sample-project
    14→npm install
    15→npx cdk synth
    16→```
    17→
    18→Start the local environment:
    19→
    20→```bash
    21→uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev
    22→```
    23→
    24→### Terraform Sample Project
    25→
    26→Clone the [Terraform sample project](https://github.com/local-web-services/sample-project-terraform) — the same order processing system built with Terraform:
    27→
    28→```bash
    29→git clone https://github.com/local-web-services/sample-project-terraform.git
    30→cd sample-project-terraform
    31→terraform init
    32→```
    33→
    34→Start the local environment, then apply:
    35→
    36→```bash
    37→# Terminal 1: Start local services
    38→uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev
    39→
    40→# Terminal 2: Apply Terraform against local endpoints
    41→terraform apply -auto-approve
    42→```
    43→
    44→### Interact with Local Services
    45→
    46→Open http://localhost:3000/_ldk/gui in your browser to see the GUI — you can watch request logs, browse DynamoDB tables, inspect S3 buckets, and interact with all your resources as you run through the steps below.
    47→
    48→In another terminal, create an order:
    49→
    50→```bash
    51→uvx --from local-web-services lws apigateway test-invoke-method \
    52→  --resource /orders \
    53→  --http-method POST \
    54→  --body '{"customerName": "Alice", "items": ["widget", "gadget"], "total": 49.99}'
    55→```
    56→
    57→Start the order processing workflow:
    58→
    59→```bash
    60→uvx --from local-web-services lws stepfunctions start-execution \
    61→  --name OrderWorkflow \
    62→  --input '{"orderId": "<ORDER_ID>", "items": ["widget", "gadget"], "total": 49.99}'
    63→```
    64→
    65→Check the workflow status:
    66→
    67→```bash
    68→uvx --from local-web-services lws stepfunctions describe-execution --execution-arn <EXECUTION_ARN>
    69→```
    70→
    71→Retrieve the order:
    72→
    73→```bash
    74→uvx --from local-web-services lws apigateway test-invoke-method \
    75→  --resource /orders/<ORDER_ID> \
    76→  --http-method GET
    77→```
    78→
    79→Store and retrieve configuration:
    80→
    81→```bash
    82→uvx --from local-web-services lws ssm put-parameter \
    83→  --name /app/table-name --value orders --type String
    84→
    85→uvx --from local-web-services lws ssm get-parameter --name /app/table-name
    86→```
    87→
    88→Store and retrieve secrets:
    89→
    90→```bash
    91→uvx --from local-web-services lws secretsmanager create-secret \
    92→  --name app/api-key --secret-string "my-secret-key"
    93→
    94→uvx --from local-web-services lws secretsmanager get-secret-value --secret-id app/api-key
    95→```
    96→
    97→Both sample projects include a full end-to-end test script (`test-orders.sh`) that runs all of these steps automatically.
    98→
    99→## Installation
   100→
   101→local-web-services requires Python 3.11+ and [uv](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/).
   102→
   103→```bash
   104→uvx --from local-web-services ldk
   105→```
   106→
   107→Or install from source:
   108→
   109→```bash
   110→git clone https://github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services.git
   111→cd local-web-services
   112→uv sync
   113→```
   114→
   115→## Quick Start (Your Own Project)
   116→
   117→### CDK Projects
   118→
   119→1. Make sure your CDK project has been synthesized:
   120→
   121→```bash
   122→cd your-cdk-project
   123→npx cdk synth
   124→```
   125→
   126→2. Start local-web-services:
   127→
   128→```bash
   129→uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev --project-dir /path/to/your-cdk-project --port 3000
   130→```
   131→
   132→`ldk` will discover your API routes, Lambda functions, DynamoDB tables, SQS queues, SNS topics, S3 buckets, Step Functions state machines, SSM parameters, and Secrets Manager secrets automatically from the CDK output.
   133→
   134→### Terraform Projects
   135→
   136→1. Initialize your Terraform project:
   137→
   138→```bash
   139→cd your-terraform-project
   140→terraform init
   141→```
   142→
   143→2. Start local-web-services:
   144→
   145→```bash
   146→uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev --project-dir /path/to/your-terraform-project
   147→```
   148→
   149→`ldk` auto-detects `.tf` files and starts all service providers in always-on mode. A `_lws_override.tf` file is generated to redirect the AWS provider to local endpoints.
   150→
   151→3. Apply your Terraform configuration:
   152→
   153→```bash
   154→terraform apply
   155→```
   156→
   157→Terraform creates resources (tables, queues, buckets, Lambda functions, API routes) against your local services. No AWS account needed.
   158→
   159→### Mode Selection
   160→
   161→`ldk dev` auto-detects your project type. To force a specific mode:
   162→
   163→```bash
   164→uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev --mode cdk        # Force CDK mode
   165→uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev --mode terraform   # Force Terraform mode
   166→```
   167→
   168→## Supported Services
   169→
   170→Each service has two dimensions of support: **IaC constructs** parsed from your project, and **API operations** emulated at runtime.
   171→
   172→### DynamoDB
   173→
   174→**CDK Constructs:**
   175→
   176→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   177→|-----------|-------------------|
   178→| `aws_dynamodb.Table` | tableName, partitionKey, sortKey, globalSecondaryIndexes |
   179→
   180→**API Operations:**
   181→
   182→| Operation | Supported |
   183→|-----------|-----------|
   184→| PutItem | Yes |
   185→| GetItem | Yes |
   186→| DeleteItem | Yes |
   187→| UpdateItem | Yes |
   188→| Query | Yes |
   189→| Scan | Yes |
   190→| BatchGetItem | Yes |
   191→| BatchWriteItem | Yes |
   192→| CreateTable | Yes |
   193→| DeleteTable | Yes |
   194→| DescribeTable | Yes |
   195→| ListTables | Yes |
   196→| TransactGetItems | Yes |
   197→| TransactWriteItems | Yes |
   198→| UpdateTable | Yes |
   199→| DescribeContinuousBackups | Yes |
   200→| UpdateTimeToLive | Yes |
   201→
   202→Backed by SQLite. Supports expression attribute names/values, filter expressions, and eventual consistency simulation.
   203→
   204→### SQS
   205→
   206→**CDK Constructs:**
   207→
   208→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   209→|-----------|-------------------|
   210→| `aws_sqs.Queue` | queueName, fifo, visibilityTimeout, contentBasedDeduplication, deadLetterQueue |
   211→
   212→**API Operations:**
   213→
   214→| Operation | Supported |
   215→|-----------|-----------|
   216→| SendMessage | Yes |
   217→| ReceiveMessage | Yes |
   218→| DeleteMessage | Yes |
   219→| CreateQueue | Yes |
   220→| DeleteQueue | Yes |
   221→| GetQueueUrl | Yes |
   222→| GetQueueAttributes | Yes |
   223→| SetQueueAttributes | Yes |
   224→| ListQueues | Yes |
   225→| PurgeQueue | Yes |
   226→| SendMessageBatch | Yes |
   227→| DeleteMessageBatch | Yes |
   228→| ChangeMessageVisibility | Yes |
   229→| ChangeMessageVisibilityBatch | Yes |
   230→| ListDeadLetterSourceQueues | Yes |
   231→
   232→Supports message attributes, long polling, and dead-letter queue wiring from RedrivePolicy.
   233→
   234→### S3
   235→
   236→**CDK Constructs:**
   237→
   238→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   239→|-----------|-------------------|
   240→| `aws_s3.Bucket` | bucketName |
   241→
   242→**API Operations:**
   243→
   244→| Operation | Supported |
   245→|-----------|-----------|
   246→| PutObject | Yes |
   247→| GetObject | Yes |
   248→| DeleteObject | Yes |
   249→| HeadObject | Yes |
   250→| ListObjectsV2 | Yes |
   251→| CreateBucket | Yes |
   252→| DeleteBucket | Yes |
   253→| HeadBucket | Yes |
   254→| ListBuckets | Yes |
   255→| CopyObject | Yes |
   256→| DeleteObjects | Yes |
   257→| PutBucketTagging | Yes |
   258→| GetBucketTagging | Yes |
   259→| DeleteBucketTagging | Yes |
   260→| GetBucketLocation | Yes |
   261→| PutBucketPolicy | Yes |
   262→| GetBucketPolicy | Yes |
   263→| PutBucketNotificationConfiguration | Yes |
   264→| GetBucketNotificationConfiguration | Yes |
   265→| CreateMultipartUpload | No |
   266→
   267→Backed by the local filesystem. Supports event notifications (ObjectCreated, ObjectRemoved), presigned URL generation, ETags, and content-type headers.
   268→
   269→### SNS
   270→
   271→**CDK Constructs:**
   272→
   273→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   274→|-----------|-------------------|
   275→| `aws_sns.Topic` | topicName |
   276→
   277→`aws_sns.Subscription` is not parsed. Subscriptions are wired at runtime via the API or auto-wired by local-web-services for Lambda/SQS targets.
   278→
   279→**API Operations:**
   280→
   281→| Operation | Supported |
   282→|-----------|-----------|
   283→| Publish | Yes |
   284→| Subscribe | Yes |
   285→| CreateTopic | Yes |
   286→| ListTopics | Yes |
   287→| ListSubscriptions | Yes |
   288→| DeleteTopic | Yes |
   289→| SetTopicAttributes | Yes |
   290→| Unsubscribe | Yes |
   291→| GetSubscriptionAttributes | Yes |
   292→| SetSubscriptionAttributes | Yes |
   293→| ConfirmSubscription | Yes |
   294→| ListSubscriptionsByTopic | Yes |
   295→
   296→Supports Lambda and SQS subscription protocols, message attributes, and fan-out to multiple subscribers.
   297→
   298→### EventBridge
   299→
   300→**CDK Constructs:**
   301→
   302→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   303→|-----------|-------------------|
   304→| `aws_events.EventBus` | eventBusName |
   305→| `aws_events.Rule` | ruleName, eventBus, eventPattern, schedule, targets |
   306→
   307→**API Operations:**
   308→
   309→| Operation | Supported |
   310→|-----------|-----------|
   311→| PutEvents | Yes |
   312→| PutRule | Yes |
   313→| PutTargets | Yes |
   314→| ListRules | Yes |
   315→| ListEventBuses | Yes |
   316→| RemoveTargets | Yes |
   317→| DeleteRule | Yes |
   318→| DescribeRule | Yes |
   319→| ListTargetsByRule | Yes |
   320→| EnableRule | Yes |
   321→| DisableRule | Yes |
   322→| TagResource | Yes |
   323→| UntagResource | Yes |
   324→| ListTagsForResource | Yes |
   325→
   326→Supports event pattern matching, schedule expressions (rate and cron), Lambda targets, and input transformations.
   327→
   328→### Step Functions
   329→
   330→**CDK Constructs:**
   331→
   332→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   333→|-----------|-------------------|
   334→| `aws_stepfunctions.StateMachine` | stateMachineName, definitionBody, stateMachineType |
   335→
   336→**API Operations:**
   337→
   338→| Operation | Supported |
   339→|-----------|-----------|
   340→| StartExecution | Yes |
   341→| StartSyncExecution | Yes |
   342→| DescribeExecution | Yes |
   343→| ListExecutions | Yes |
   344→| ListStateMachines | Yes |
   345→| CreateStateMachine | Yes |
   346→| StopExecution | Yes |
   347→| GetExecutionHistory | Yes |
   348→| UpdateStateMachine | Yes |
   349→
   350→State types: Task, Pass, Choice, Wait, Succeed, Fail, Parallel, Map. Supports JSONPath (InputPath, OutputPath, ResultPath), error handling (Retry, Catch), and Standard & Express workflows.
   351→
   352→### Cognito
   353→
   354→**CDK Constructs:**
   355→
   356→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   357→|-----------|-------------------|
   358→| `aws_cognito.UserPool` | userPoolName, lambdaTriggers (preAuthentication, postConfirmation), passwordPolicy |
   359→| `aws_cognito.UserPoolClient` | userPool |
   360→
   361→**API Operations:**
   362→
   363→| Operation | Supported |
   364→|-----------|-----------|
   365→| SignUp | Yes |
   366→| ConfirmSignUp | Yes |
   367→| InitiateAuth | Yes (USER_PASSWORD_AUTH) |
   368→| JWKS endpoint | Yes |
   369→| CreateUserPoolClient | Yes |
   370→| DeleteUserPoolClient | Yes |
   371→| DescribeUserPoolClient | Yes |
   372→| ListUserPoolClients | Yes |
   373→| AdminCreateUser | Yes |
   374→| AdminDeleteUser | Yes |
   375→| AdminGetUser | Yes |
   376→| UpdateUserPool | Yes |
   377→| ListUsers | Yes |
   378→| ForgotPassword | No |
   379→| ChangePassword | No |
   380→| GlobalSignOut | No |
   381→
   382→Backed by SQLite. Supports JWT token generation (ID, access, refresh), user attributes, and password hashing.
   383→
   384→### Lambda
   385→
   386→**CDK Constructs:**
   387→
   388→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   389→|-----------|-------------------|
   390→| `aws_lambda.Function` | handler, runtime, code, timeout, memorySize, environment |
   391→
   392→**Management API (Terraform mode):**
   393→
   394→| Operation | Supported |
   395→|-----------|-----------|
   396→| CreateFunction | Yes |
   397→| GetFunction | Yes |
   398→| DeleteFunction | Yes |
   399→| ListFunctions | Yes |
   400→| Invoke | Yes |
   401→| UpdateFunctionConfiguration | Yes |
   402→| UpdateFunctionCode | Yes |
   403→| TagResource | Yes |
   404→| UntagResource | Yes |
   405→| ListEventSourceMappings | Yes |
   406→
   407→Runs functions locally using Python or Node.js runtimes. Supports timeout enforcement, realistic context objects, and environment variable injection. In CDK mode, functions are discovered from the cloud assembly. In Terraform mode, functions are created dynamically via the management API.
   408→
   409→### API Gateway
   410→
   411→**CDK Constructs:**
   412→
   413→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   414→|-----------|-------------------|
   415→| `aws_apigateway.RestApi` | routes, methods, integrations |
   416→| `aws_apigatewayv2.HttpApi` | routes, integrations |
   417→
   418→**REST API (V1) Management:**
   419→
   420→CreateRestApi, GetRestApi, DeleteRestApi, CreateResource, PutMethod, PutIntegration, CreateDeployment, CreateStage.
   421→
   422→**HTTP API (V2) Management:**
   423→
   424→CreateApi, GetApi, DeleteApi, CreateRoute, CreateIntegration, CreateStage, ListRoutes, ListIntegrations, ListStages.
   425→
   426→Supports both REST API (V1) and HTTP API (V2) with Lambda proxy integration. Routes requests to local Lambda functions with path parameters, query parameters, and request/response mapping.
   427→
   428→### ECS
   429→
   430→**CDK Constructs:**
   431→
   432→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   433→|-----------|-------------------|
   434→| `aws_ecs.TaskDefinition` | containerDefinitions |
   435→| `aws_ecs.FargateService` / `aws_ecs.Ec2Service` | taskDefinition |
   436→| `aws_elasticloadbalancingv2.ApplicationListenerRule` | conditions, actions |
   437→
   438→Runs services as local subprocesses. Supports health checking, service discovery, file watching with auto-restart, and port mapping. Supports local command overrides via `ldk.local_command` metadata. CDK mode only.
   439→
   440→### IAM & STS
   441→
   442→Stub APIs that return AWS-compatible responses for Terraform compatibility. IAM role and policy operations are accepted and stored in memory (CreateRole, GetRole, DeleteRole, CreatePolicy, GetPolicy, DeletePolicy, AttachRolePolicy, DetachRolePolicy, CreatePolicyVersion, ListRoles, ListPolicies). STS returns dummy credentials and caller identity (GetCallerIdentity, AssumeRole).
   443→
   444→### SSM Parameter Store
   445→
   446→**CDK Constructs:**
   447→
   448→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   449→|-----------|-------------------|
   450→| `aws_ssm.StringParameter` | Name, Type, Value, Description |
   451→
   452→**API Operations:**
   453→
   454→| Operation | Supported |
   455→|-----------|-----------|
   456→| PutParameter | Yes |
   457→| GetParameter | Yes |
   458→| GetParameters | Yes |
   459→| GetParametersByPath | Yes |
   460→| DeleteParameter | Yes |
   461→| DeleteParameters | Yes |
   462→| DescribeParameters | Yes |
   463→| AddTagsToResource | Yes |
   464→| RemoveTagsFromResource | Yes |
   465→| ListTagsForResource | Yes |
   466→
   467→In-memory parameter store supporting String, StringList, and SecureString types. Supports versioning (auto-incremented on overwrite), descriptions, and tags. In CDK mode, parameters defined in the CloudFormation template are pre-seeded on startup.
   468→
   469→### Secrets Manager
   470→
   471→**CDK Constructs:**
   472→
   473→| Construct | Parsed Properties |
   474→|-----------|-------------------|
   475→| `aws_secretsmanager.Secret` | Name, Description, SecretString, GenerateSecretString |
   476→
   477→**API Operations:**
   478→
   479→| Operation | Supported |
   480→|-----------|-----------|
   481→| CreateSecret | Yes |
   482→| GetSecretValue | Yes |
   483→| PutSecretValue | Yes |
   484→| UpdateSecret | Yes |
   485→| DeleteSecret | Yes |
   486→| DescribeSecret | Yes |
   487→| ListSecrets | Yes |
   488→| RestoreSecret | Yes |
   489→| TagResource | Yes |
   490→| UntagResource | Yes |
   491→| ListSecretVersionIds | Yes |
   492→
   493→In-memory secret store supporting version staging (AWSCURRENT/AWSPREVIOUS), soft delete with optional recovery, and tags. In CDK mode, secrets defined in the CloudFormation template are pre-seeded on startup.
   494→
   495→## Development
   496→
   497→All development tasks are available through `make`:
   498→
   499→```bash
   500→make install       # Install dependencies
   501→make test          # Run test suite
   502→make lint          # Run linter
   503→make format        # Auto-format code
   504→make check         # Run all checks (lint, format, complexity, tests)
   505→```
   506→
   507→Run `make` with no arguments to see all available targets.
   508→
   509→## Documentation
   510→
   511→Visit [https://local-web-services.github.io/www/](https://local-web-services.github.io/www/) for full documentation.
   512→
   513→## Contributing
   514→
   515→See [CONTRIBUTING.md](CONTRIBUTING.md) for guidelines on how to contribute.
   516→
   517→## License
   518→
   519→This project is licensed under the MIT License. See [LICENSE](LICENSE) for details.
   520→

file.content:
# local-web-services

Run your AWS CDK and Terraform applications locally. local-web-services reads your CDK cloud assembly or Terraform configuration and spins up local emulations of API Gateway, Lambda, DynamoDB, SQS, SNS, S3, Step Functions, Cognito, EventBridge, SSM Parameter Store, Secrets Manager, and more — so you can develop and test without deploying to AWS.

## Try It Out

### CDK Sample Project

Clone the [CDK sample project](https://github.com/local-web-services/sample-project) — a serverless order processing system with API Gateway, Lambda, DynamoDB, SQS, S3, SNS, and Step Functions:

```bash
git clone https://github.com/local-web-services/sample-project.git
cd sample-project
npm install
npx cdk synth
```

Start the local environment:

```bash
uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev
```

### Terraform Sample Project

Clone the [Terraform sample project](https://github.com/local-web-services/sample-project-terraform) — the same order processing system built with Terraform:

```bash
git clone https://github.com/local-web-services/sample-project-terraform.git
cd sample-project-terraform
terraform init
```

Start the local environment, then apply:

```bash
# Terminal 1: Start local services
uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev

# Terminal 2: Apply Terraform against local endpoints
terraform apply -auto-approve
```

### Interact with Local Services

Open http://localhost:3000/_ldk/gui in your browser to see the GUI — you can watch request logs, browse DynamoDB tables, inspect S3 buckets, and interact with all your resources as you run through the steps below.

In another terminal, create an order:

```bash
uvx --from local-web-services lws apigateway test-invoke-method \
  --resource /orders \
  --http-method POST \
  --body '{"customerName": "Alice", "items": ["widget", "gadget"], "total": 49.99}'
```

Start the order processing workflow:

```bash
uvx --from local-web-services lws stepfunctions start-execution \
  --name OrderWorkflow \
  --input '{"orderId": "<ORDER_ID>", "items": ["widget", "gadget"], "total": 49.99}'
```

Check the workflow status:

```bash
uvx --from local-web-services lws stepfunctions describe-execution --execution-arn <EXECUTION_ARN>
```

Retrieve the order:

```bash
uvx --from local-web-services lws apigateway test-invoke-method \
  --resource /orders/<ORDER_ID> \
  --http-method GET
```

Store and retrieve configuration:

```bash
uvx --from local-web-services lws ssm put-parameter \
  --name /app/table-name --value orders --type String

uvx --from local-web-services lws ssm get-parameter --name /app/table-name
```

Store and retrieve secrets:

```bash
uvx --from local-web-services lws secretsmanager create-secret \
  --name app/api-key --secret-string "my-secret-key"

uvx --from local-web-services lws secretsmanager get-secret-value --secret-id app/api-key
```

Both sample projects include a full end-to-end test script (`test-orders.sh`) that runs all of these steps automatically.

## Installation

local-web-services requires Python 3.11+ and [uv](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/).

```bash
uvx --from local-web-services ldk
```

Or install from source:

```bash
git clone https://github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services.git
cd local-web-services
uv sync
```

## Quick Start (Your Own Project)

### CDK Projects

1. Make sure your CDK project has been synthesized:

```bash
cd your-cdk-project
npx cdk synth
```

2. Start local-web-services:

```bash
uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev --project-dir /path/to/your-cdk-project --port 3000
```

`ldk` will discover your API routes, Lambda functions, DynamoDB tables, SQS queues, SNS topics, S3 buckets, Step Functions state machines, SSM parameters, and Secrets Manager secrets automatically from the CDK output.

### Terraform Projects

1. Initialize your Terraform project:

```bash
cd your-terraform-project
terraform init
```

2. Start local-web-services:

```bash
uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev --project-dir /path/to/your-terraform-project
```

`ldk` auto-detects `.tf` files and starts all service providers in always-on mode. A `_lws_override.tf` file is generated to redirect the AWS provider to local endpoints.

3. Apply your Terraform configuration:

```bash
terraform apply
```

Terraform creates resources (tables, queues, buckets, Lambda functions, API routes) against your local services. No AWS account needed.

### Mode Selection

`ldk dev` auto-detects your project type. To force a specific mode:

```bash
uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev --mode cdk        # Force CDK mode
uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev --mode terraform   # Force Terraform mode
```

## Supported Services

Each service has two dimensions of support: **IaC constructs** parsed from your project, and **API operations** emulated at runtime.

### DynamoDB

**CDK Constructs:**

| Construct | Parsed Properties |
|-----------|-------------------|
| `aws_dynamodb.Table` | tableName, partitionKey, sortKey, globalSecondaryIndexes |

**API Operations:**

| Operation | Supported |
|-----------|-----------|
| PutItem | Yes |
| GetItem | Yes |
| DeleteItem | Yes |
| UpdateItem | Yes |
| Query | Yes |
| Scan | Yes |
| BatchGetItem | Yes |
| BatchWriteItem | Yes |
| CreateTable | Yes |
| DeleteTable | Yes |
| DescribeTable | Yes |
| ListTables | Yes |
| TransactGetItems | Yes |
| TransactWriteItems | Yes |
| UpdateTable | Yes |
| DescribeContinuousBackups | Yes |
| UpdateTimeToLive | Yes |

Backed by SQLite. Supports expression attribute names/values, filter expressions, and eventual consistency simulation.

### SQS

**CDK Constructs:**

| Construct | Parsed Properties |
|-----------|-------------------|
| `aws_sqs.Queue` | queueName, fifo, visibilityTimeout, contentBasedDeduplication, deadLetterQueue |

**API Operations:**

| Operation | Supported |
|-----------|-----------|
| SendMessage | Yes |
| ReceiveMessage | Yes |
| DeleteMessage | Yes |
| CreateQueue | Yes |
| DeleteQueue | Yes |
| GetQueueUrl | Yes |
| GetQueueAttributes | Yes |
| SetQueueAttributes | Yes |
| ListQueues | Yes |
| PurgeQueue | Yes |
| SendMessageBatch | Yes |
| DeleteMessageBatch | Yes |
| ChangeMessageVisibility | Yes |
| ChangeMessageVisibilityBatch | Yes |
| ListDeadLetterSourceQueues | Yes |

Supports message attributes, long polling, and dead-letter queue wiring from RedrivePolicy.

### S3

**CDK Constructs:**

| Construct | Parsed Properties |
|-----------|-------------------|
| `aws_s3.Bucket` | bucketName |

**API Operations:**

| Operation | Supported |
|-----------|-----------|
| PutObject | Yes |
| GetObject | Yes |
| DeleteObject | Yes |
| HeadObject | Yes |
| ListObjectsV2 | Yes |
| CreateBucket | Yes |
| DeleteBucket | Yes |
| HeadBucket | Yes |
| ListBuckets | Yes |
| CopyObject | Yes |
| DeleteObjects | Yes |
| PutBucketTagging | Yes |
| GetBucketTagging | Yes |
| DeleteBucketTagging | Yes |
| GetBucketLocation | Yes |
| PutBucketPolicy | Yes |
| GetBucketPolicy | Yes |
| PutBucketNotificationConfiguration | Yes |
| GetBucketNotificationConfiguration | Yes |
| CreateMultipartUpload | No |

Backed by the local filesystem. Supports event notifications (ObjectCreated, ObjectRemoved), presigned URL generation, ETags, and content-type headers.

### SNS

**CDK Constructs:**

| Construct | Parsed Properties |
|-----------|-------------------|
| `aws_sns.Topic` | topicName |

`aws_sns.Subscription` is not parsed. Subscriptions are wired at runtime via the API or auto-wired by local-web-services for Lambda/SQS targets.

**API Operations:**

| Operation | Supported |
|-----------|-----------|
| Publish | Yes |
| Subscribe | Yes |
| CreateTopic | Yes |
| ListTopics | Yes |
| ListSubscriptions | Yes |
| DeleteTopic | Yes |
| SetTopicAttributes | Yes |
| Unsubscribe | Yes |
| GetSubscriptionAttributes | Yes |
| SetSubscriptionAttributes | Yes |
| ConfirmSubscription | Yes |
| ListSubscriptionsByTopic | Yes |

Supports Lambda and SQS subscription protocols, message attributes, and fan-out to multiple subscribers.

### EventBridge

**CDK Constructs:**

| Construct | Parsed Properties |
|-----------|-------------------|
| `aws_events.EventBus` | eventBusName |
| `aws_events.Rule` | ruleName, eventBus, eventPattern, schedule, targets |

**API Operations:**

| Operation | Supported |
|-----------|-----------|
| PutEvents | Yes |
| PutRule | Yes |
| PutTargets | Yes |
| ListRules | Yes |
| ListEventBuses | Yes |
| RemoveTargets | Yes |
| DeleteRule | Yes |
| DescribeRule | Yes |
| ListTargetsByRule | Yes |
| EnableRule | Yes |
| DisableRule | Yes |
| TagResource | Yes |
| UntagResource | Yes |
| ListTagsForResource | Yes |

Supports event pattern matching, schedule expressions (rate and cron), Lambda targets, and input transformations.

### Step Functions

**CDK Constructs:**

| Construct | Parsed Properties |
|-----------|-------------------|
| `aws_stepfunctions.StateMachine` | stateMachineName, definitionBody, stateMachineType |

**API Operations:**

| Operation | Supported |
|-----------|-----------|
| StartExecution | Yes |
| StartSyncExecution | Yes |
| DescribeExecution | Yes |
| ListExecutions | Yes |
| ListStateMachines | Yes |
| CreateStateMachine | Yes |
| StopExecution | Yes |
| GetExecutionHistory | Yes |
| UpdateStateMachine | Yes |

State types: Task, Pass, Choice, Wait, Succeed, Fail, Parallel, Map. Supports JSONPath (InputPath, OutputPath, ResultPath), error handling (Retry, Catch), and Standard & Express workflows.

### Cognito

**CDK Constructs:**

| Construct | Parsed Properties |
|-----------|-------------------|
| `aws_cognito.UserPool` | userPoolName, lambdaTriggers (preAuthentication, postConfirmation), passwordPolicy |
| `aws_cognito.UserPoolClient` | userPool |

**API Operations:**

| Operation | Supported |
|-----------|-----------|
| SignUp | Yes |
| ConfirmSignUp | Yes |
| InitiateAuth | Yes (USER_PASSWORD_AUTH) |
| JWKS endpoint | Yes |
| CreateUserPoolClient | Yes |
| DeleteUserPoolClient | Yes |
| DescribeUserPoolClient | Yes |
| ListUserPoolClients | Yes |
| AdminCreateUser | Yes |
| AdminDeleteUser | Yes |
| AdminGetUser | Yes |
| UpdateUserPool | Yes |
| ListUsers | Yes |
| ForgotPassword | No |
| ChangePassword | No |
| GlobalSignOut | No |

Backed by SQLite. Supports JWT token generation (ID, access, refresh), user attributes, and password hashing.

### Lambda

**CDK Constructs:**

| Construct | Parsed Properties |
|-----------|-------------------|
| `aws_lambda.Function` | handler, runtime, code, timeout, memorySize, environment |

**Management API (Terraform mode):**

| Operation | Supported |
|-----------|-----------|
| CreateFunction | Yes |
| GetFunction | Yes |
| DeleteFunction | Yes |
| ListFunctions | Yes |
| Invoke | Yes |
| UpdateFunctionConfiguration | Yes |
| UpdateFunctionCode | Yes |
| TagResource | Yes |
| UntagResource | Yes |
| ListEventSourceMappings | Yes |

Runs functions locally using Python or Node.js runtimes. Supports timeout enforcement, realistic context objects, and environment variable injection. In CDK mode, functions are discovered from the cloud assembly. In Terraform mode, functions are created dynamically via the management API.

### API Gateway

**CDK Constructs:**

| Construct | Parsed Properties |
|-----------|-------------------|
| `aws_apigateway.RestApi` | routes, methods, integrations |
| `aws_apigatewayv2.HttpApi` | routes, integrations |

**REST API (V1) Management:**

CreateRestApi, GetRestApi, DeleteRestApi, CreateResource, PutMethod, PutIntegration, CreateDeployment, CreateStage.

**HTTP API (V2) Management:**

CreateApi, GetApi, DeleteApi, CreateRoute, CreateIntegration, CreateStage, ListRoutes, ListIntegrations, ListStages.

Supports both REST API (V1) and HTTP API (V2) with Lambda proxy integration. Routes requests to local Lambda functions with path parameters, query parameters, and request/response mapping.

### ECS

**CDK Constructs:**

| Construct | Parsed Properties |
|-----------|-------------------|
| `aws_ecs.TaskDefinition` | containerDefinitions |
| `aws_ecs.FargateService` / `aws_ecs.Ec2Service` | taskDefinition |
| `aws_elasticloadbalancingv2.ApplicationListenerRule` | conditions, actions |

Runs services as local subprocesses. Supports health checking, service discovery, file watching with auto-restart, and port mapping. Supports local command overrides via `ldk.local_command` metadata. CDK mode only.

### IAM & STS

Stub APIs that return AWS-compatible responses for Terraform compatibility. IAM role and policy operations are accepted and stored in memory (CreateRole, GetRole, DeleteRole, CreatePolicy, GetPolicy, DeletePolicy, AttachRolePolicy, DetachRolePolicy, CreatePolicyVersion, ListRoles, ListPolicies). STS returns dummy credentials and caller identity (GetCallerIdentity, AssumeRole).

### SSM Parameter Store

**CDK Constructs:**

| Construct | Parsed Properties |
|-----------|-------------------|
| `aws_ssm.StringParameter` | Name, Type, Value, Description |

**API Operations:**

| Operation | Supported |
|-----------|-----------|
| PutParameter | Yes |
| GetParameter | Yes |
| GetParameters | Yes |
| GetParametersByPath | Yes |
| DeleteParameter | Yes |
| DeleteParameters | Yes |
| DescribeParameters | Yes |
| AddTagsToResource | Yes |
| RemoveTagsFromResource | Yes |
| ListTagsForResource | Yes |

In-memory parameter store supporting String, StringList, and SecureString types. Supports versioning (auto-incremented on overwrite), descriptions, and tags. In CDK mode, parameters defined in the CloudFormation template are pre-seeded on startup.

### Secrets Manager

**CDK Constructs:**

| Construct | Parsed Properties |
|-----------|-------------------|
| `aws_secretsmanager.Secret` | Name, Description, SecretString, GenerateSecretString |

**API Operations:**

| Operation | Supported |
|-----------|-----------|
| CreateSecret | Yes |
| GetSecretValue | Yes |
| PutSecretValue | Yes |
| UpdateSecret | Yes |
| DeleteSecret | Yes |
| DescribeSecret | Yes |
| ListSecrets | Yes |
| RestoreSecret | Yes |
| TagResource | Yes |
| UntagResource | Yes |
| ListSecretVersionIds | Yes |

In-memory secret store supporting version staging (AWSCURRENT/AWSPREVIOUS), soft delete with optional recovery, and tags. In CDK mode, secrets defined in the CloudFormation template are pre-seeded on startup.

## Development

All development tasks are available through `make`:

```bash
make install       # Install dependencies
make test          # Run test suite
make lint          # Run linter
make format        # Auto-format code
make check         # Run all checks (lint, format, complexity, tests)
```

Run `make` with no arguments to see all available targets.

## Documentation

Visit [https://local-web-services.github.io/www/](https://local-web-services.github.io/www/) for full documentation.

## Contributing

See [CONTRIBUTING.md](CONTRIBUTING.md) for guidelines on how to contribute.

## License

This project is licensed under the MIT License. See [LICENSE](LICENSE) for details.

file.content:
# ldk-sample-project

A serverless order processing system built with AWS CDK and designed for local development with [LDK (Local Development Kit)](https://github.com/local-development-kit/ldk).

## Architecture

The application implements an event-driven order processing workflow using the following AWS services:

- **API Gateway (HTTP)** - REST endpoints for creating and retrieving orders
- **Lambda** - Four Node.js 20.x functions handling order lifecycle
- **DynamoDB** - Order persistence (`Orders` table)
- **SQS** - Asynchronous order processing queue with dead letter queue
- **Step Functions** - `OrderWorkflow` state machine orchestrating processing, receipt generation, and notification
- **S3** - Receipt storage
- **SNS** - Order status notifications
- **SSM Parameter Store** - Application configuration parameters
- **Secrets Manager** - Secure storage for API keys and credentials

### Request Flow

```
POST /orders
  -> CreateOrderFunction
       -> DynamoDB (store order)
       -> SQS (enqueue for processing)

Step Functions (OrderWorkflow):
  ProcessOrder -> GenerateReceipt -> NotifyCustomer -> OrderComplete

GET /orders/{id}
  -> GetOrderFunction
       -> DynamoDB (retrieve order)
```

## Project Structure

```
ldk-sample-project/
├── bin/app.ts                      # CDK app entry point
├── lib/order-processing-stack.ts   # CDK stack definition
├── lambda/
│   ├── create-order/index.js       # Create order, store in DynamoDB, enqueue to SQS
│   ├── get-order/index.js          # Retrieve order from DynamoDB
│   ├── process-order/index.js      # Process order, publish SNS notification
│   └── generate-receipt/index.js   # Generate receipt, store in S3
├── test-orders.sh                  # End-to-end test script
├── cdk.json                        # CDK configuration
└── package.json                    # Dependencies
```

## Prerequisites

- [Node.js](https://nodejs.org/) >= 20.x
- [AWS CDK](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cdk/) >= 2.170.0
- [LDK](https://github.com/local-development-kit/ldk) for local development

## Setup

```bash
npm install
npx cdk synth
```

## Local Development

Start the local development environment with LDK:

```bash
ldk dev
```

This starts all services locally (API Gateway, DynamoDB, SQS, S3, SNS, Step Functions, SSM Parameter Store, Secrets Manager) and watches for file changes.

### Available Local Resources

| Type          | Name               | Details                         |
|---------------|--------------------|---------------------------------|
| API Route     | POST /orders       | Create a new order              |
| API Route     | GET /orders/{id}   | Retrieve an order               |
| Table         | Orders             | Order data (partition key: orderId) |
| Queue         | order-queue        | Order processing queue          |
| Queue         | order-dlq          | Dead letter queue               |
| Bucket        | ReceiptsBucket     | Receipt storage                 |
| Topic         | order-notifications         | Order status notifications        |
| Parameter     | /orders/config/max-items    | Max items per order config        |
| Secret        | orders/notification-api-key | Notification API key              |
| State Machine | OrderWorkflow               | Order processing workflow         |

## Running Tests

Run the end-to-end test script while `ldk dev` is running:

```bash
bash test-orders.sh
```

This script:
1. Creates an order via POST /orders
2. Starts the OrderWorkflow state machine
3. Polls until the workflow completes
4. Retrieves the order via GET /orders/{id}

### Example Output

```
=== Creating order ===
Order ID: dbdbbfe3-a4d8-408d-ad55-78b1de2e3873

=== Starting OrderWorkflow ===

=== Polling for workflow completion ===
  Attempt 1: RUNNING
  Attempt 2: SUCCEEDED

Workflow output:
{
  "processed": 1,
  "results": [
    {
      "orderId": "dbdbbfe3-a4d8-408d-ad55-78b1de2e3873",
      "status": "PROCESSED"
    }
  ]
}

=== Getting order ===
{
  "orderId": "dbdbbfe3-a4d8-408d-ad55-78b1de2e3873",
  "customerName": "Alice",
  "items": ["widget", "gadget"],
  "total": 49.99,
  "createdAt": "2026-02-08T16:41:20.649Z"
}
```

## Deploying to AWS

```bash
npx cdk deploy
```

## License

MIT

1→# lws-sample-project-terraform
     2→
     3→A serverless order processing system built with [Terraform](https://www.terraform.io/) / [OpenTofu](https://opentofu.org/) and designed for local development with [Local Web Services](https://github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services).
     4→
     5→## Architecture
     6→
     7→The application implements an event-driven order processing workflow using the following AWS services:
     8→
     9→- **API Gateway (HTTP)** - REST endpoints for creating and retrieving orders
    10→- **Lambda** - Four Node.js 20.x functions handling order lifecycle
    11→- **DynamoDB** - Order persistence (`Orders` table)
    12→- **SQS** - Asynchronous order processing queue with dead letter queue
    13→- **Step Functions** - `OrderWorkflow` state machine orchestrating processing, receipt generation, and notification
    14→- **S3** - Receipt storage
    15→- **SNS** - Order status notifications
    16→- **SSM Parameter Store** - Application configuration parameters
    17→- **Secrets Manager** - Secure storage for API keys and credentials
    18→
    19→### Request Flow
    20→
    21→```
    22→POST /orders
    23→  -> CreateOrderFunction
    24→       -> DynamoDB (store order)
    25→       -> SQS (enqueue for processing)
    26→
    27→Step Functions (OrderWorkflow):
    28→  ValidateOrder -> ProcessPayment -> GenerateReceipt -> NotifyCustomer -> OrderComplete
    29→
    30→GET /orders/{id}
    31→  -> GetOrderFunction
    32→       -> DynamoDB (retrieve order)
    33→```
    34→
    35→## Project Structure
    36→
    37→```
    38→lws-sample-project-terraform/
    39→├── main.tf                            # Provider configuration
    40→├── variables.tf                       # Input variables
    41→├── outputs.tf                         # Stack outputs
    42→├── dynamodb.tf                        # DynamoDB table
    43→├── sqs.tf                             # SQS queues
    44→├── s3.tf                              # S3 bucket
    45→├── sns.tf                             # SNS topic
    46→├── ssm.tf                             # SSM Parameter Store parameters
    47→├── secretsmanager.tf                  # Secrets Manager secrets
    48→├── iam.tf                             # IAM roles and policies
    49→├── lambda.tf                          # Lambda functions
    50→├── apigateway.tf                      # HTTP API Gateway
    51→├── stepfunctions.tf                   # Step Functions state machine
    52→├── lambda/
    53→│   ├── create-order/index.js          # Create order, store in DynamoDB, enqueue to SQS
    54→│   ├── get-order/index.js             # Retrieve order from DynamoDB
    55→│   ├── process-order/index.js         # Process order, publish SNS notification
    56→│   └── generate-receipt/index.js      # Generate receipt, store in S3
    57→└── test-orders.sh                     # End-to-end test script
    58→```
    59→
    60→## Prerequisites
    61→
    62→- [uv](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/getting-started/installation/) (for running local-web-services)
    63→- [Terraform](https://www.terraform.io/) >= 1.0 or [OpenTofu](https://opentofu.org/) >= 1.6
    64→- Node.js 18+
    65→
    66→## Setup
    67→
    68→Install Lambda function dependencies:
    69→
    70→```bash
    71→cd lambda/create-order && npm install && cd ../..
    72→cd lambda/get-order && npm install && cd ../..
    73→cd lambda/process-order && npm install && cd ../..
    74→cd lambda/generate-receipt && npm install && cd ../..
    75→```
    76→
    77→Initialize Terraform (or OpenTofu):
    78→
    79→```bash
    80→terraform init
    81→# or
    82→tofu init
    83→```
    84→
    85→## Local Development
    86→
    87→### How It Works
    88→
    89→When you run `ldk dev` in this directory, it:
    90→
    91→1. **Detects** the `.tf` files and enters Terraform mode automatically
    92→2. **Starts** all AWS service providers locally (DynamoDB, SQS, S3, SNS, Step Functions, API Gateway, Lambda, IAM, STS, SSM, Secrets Manager)

file.content:
# lws-sample-project-terraform

A serverless order processing system built with [Terraform](https://www.terraform.io/) / [OpenTofu](https://opentofu.org/) and designed for local development with [Local Web Services](https://github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services).

## Architecture

The application implements an event-driven order processing workflow using the following AWS services:

- **API Gateway (HTTP)** - REST endpoints for creating and retrieving orders
- **Lambda** - Four Node.js 20.x functions handling order lifecycle
- **DynamoDB** - Order persistence (`Orders` table)
- **SQS** - Asynchronous order processing queue with dead letter queue
- **Step Functions** - `OrderWorkflow` state machine orchestrating processing, receipt generation, and notification
- **S3** - Receipt storage
- **SNS** - Order status notifications
- **SSM Parameter Store** - Application configuration parameters
- **Secrets Manager** - Secure storage for API keys and credentials

### Request Flow

```
POST /orders
  -> CreateOrderFunction
       -> DynamoDB (store order)
       -> SQS (enqueue for processing)

Step Functions (OrderWorkflow):
  ValidateOrder -> ProcessPayment -> GenerateReceipt -> NotifyCustomer -> OrderComplete

GET /orders/{id}
  -> GetOrderFunction
       -> DynamoDB (retrieve order)
```

## Project Structure

```
lws-sample-project-terraform/
├── main.tf                            # Provider configuration
├── variables.tf                       # Input variables
├── outputs.tf                         # Stack outputs
├── dynamodb.tf                        # DynamoDB table
├── sqs.tf                             # SQS queues
├── s3.tf                              # S3 bucket
├── sns.tf                             # SNS topic
├── ssm.tf                             # SSM Parameter Store parameters
├── secretsmanager.tf                  # Secrets Manager secrets
├── iam.tf                             # IAM roles and policies
├── lambda.tf                          # Lambda functions
├── apigateway.tf                      # HTTP API Gateway
├── stepfunctions.tf                   # Step Functions state machine
├── lambda/
│   ├── create-order/index.js          # Create order, store in DynamoDB, enqueue to SQS
│   ├── get-order/index.js             # Retrieve order from DynamoDB
│   ├── process-order/index.js         # Process order, publish SNS notification
│   └── generate-receipt/index.js      # Generate receipt, store in S3
└── test-orders.sh                     # End-to-end test script
```

## Prerequisites

- [uv](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/getting-started/installation/) (for running local-web-services)
- [Terraform](https://www.terraform.io/) >= 1.0 or [OpenTofu](https://opentofu.org/) >= 1.6
- Node.js 18+

## Setup

Install Lambda function dependencies:

```bash
cd lambda/create-order && npm install && cd ../..
cd lambda/get-order && npm install && cd ../..
cd lambda/process-order && npm install && cd ../..
cd lambda/generate-receipt && npm install && cd ../..
```

Initialize Terraform (or OpenTofu):

```bash
terraform init
# or
tofu init
```

## Local Development

### How It Works

When you run `ldk dev` in this directory, it:

1. **Detects** the `.tf` files and enters Terraform mode automatically
2. **Starts** all AWS service providers locally (DynamoDB, SQS, S3, SNS, Step Functions, API Gateway, Lambda, IAM, STS, SSM, Secrets Manager)
3. **Generates** a `_lws_override.tf` file that redirects all AWS provider endpoints to your local services (this file is auto-added to `.gitignore`)
4. **Watches** for file changes and reloads automatically

You then run `terraform apply` (or `tofu apply`) against these local endpoints — no AWS account needed.

### Start the local environment

```bash
# Terminal 1: Start local services
uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev
```

### Apply Terraform / OpenTofu

```bash
# Terminal 2: Apply against local endpoints
terraform apply -auto-approve
# or
tofu apply -auto-approve
```

This creates all resources (tables, queues, Lambda functions, API routes, etc.) against your local services.

### Available Local Resources

| Type          | Name               | Details                         |
|---------------|--------------------|---------------------------------|
| API Route     | POST /orders       | Create a new order              |
| API Route     | GET /orders/{id}   | Retrieve an order               |
| Table         | Orders             | Order data (partition key: orderId) |
| Queue         | order-queue        | Order processing queue          |
| Queue         | order-dlq          | Dead letter queue               |
| Bucket        | ReceiptsBucket     | Receipt storage                 |
| Topic         | order-notifications         | Order status notifications        |
| Parameter     | /orders/config/max-items    | Max items per order config        |
| Secret        | orders/notification-api-key | Notification API key              |
| State Machine | OrderWorkflow               | Order processing workflow         |

## Running Tests

Run the end-to-end test script while `ldk dev` is running and after `terraform apply` / `tofu apply`:

```bash
bash test-orders.sh
```

This script:
1. Creates an order via POST /orders
2. Starts the OrderWorkflow state machine
3. Polls until the workflow completes
4. Retrieves the order via GET /orders/{id}

### Example Output

```
=== Creating order ===
Order ID: dbdbbfe3-a4d8-408d-ad55-78b1de2e3873

=== Starting OrderWorkflow ===

=== Polling for workflow completion ===
  Attempt 1: RUNNING
  Attempt 2: SUCCEEDED

Workflow output:
{
  "processed": 1,
  "results": [
    {
      "orderId": "dbdbbfe3-a4d8-408d-ad55-78b1de2e3873",
      "status": "PROCESSED"
    }
  ]
}

=== Getting order ===
{
  "orderId": "dbdbbfe3-a4d8-408d-ad55-78b1de2e3873",
  "customerName": "Alice",
  "items": ["widget", "gadget"],
  "total": 49.99,
  "createdAt": "2026-02-08T16:41:20.649Z"
}
```

## Deploying to AWS

To deploy to real AWS (instead of local), remove the `_lws_override.tf` file (if present) and run:

```bash
terraform apply
# or
tofu apply
```

## License

MIT

1→# Local Web Services - Documentation Site
     2→
     3→Documentation site for the [Local Web Services](https://github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services) project.
     4→
     5→**Live site:** https://local-web-services.github.io/www/
     6→
     7→## About
     8→
     9→Local Web Services provides two complementary CLI tools for local AWS CDK development:
    10→
    11→- **ldk** - Runs your AWS CDK applications locally as a development server
    12→- **lws** - AWS CLI-style commands for interacting with local services
    13→
    14→## Local preview
    15→
    16→Open `index.html` in a browser.
    17→
    18→## Deployment
    19→
    20→The site deploys automatically on push to `main` via the GitHub Actions workflow in `.github/workflows/deploy.yml`. To enable it:
    21→
    22→1. Go to the repository **Settings > Pages**
    23→2. Under **Build and deployment**, set the source to **GitHub Actions**
    24→

1→ 2→ 3→ 4→ 5→ 6→ Local Web Services - Run AWS CDK & Terraform Apps Locally 7→ 8→ 9→ 10→ 11→ 12→
13→
14→ Local Web Services 15→
    16→
  • What

Local Web Services

30→

Run your AWS CDK and Terraform applications locally with ldk dev.
31→Interact with local services using lws.
32→No credentials. No cost. No waiting.

33→
34→ Get Started 35→ View on GitHub 36→
37→
38→ uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev 39→
40→
41→
42→ 43→
44→
45→

What is Local Web Services?

46→

Local Web Services is an open-source tool that reads your AWS CDK or Terraform project and recreates your entire application locally. It supports both CDK (via cdk synth) and Terraform (via terraform apply) with automatic project type detection. Two complementary CLI tools work together: ldk runs your infrastructure, and lws lets you interact with it.

47→ 48→
49→
50→
⚡
51→

ldk

52→

The development server. Parses your CDK or Terraform project and spins up local providers for every AWS service you use — DynamoDB, Lambda, S3, SQS, and more. Your entire stack runs locally.

53→
54→
55→
🔧
56→

lws

57→

AWS CLI for local services. Interact with your running local stack using familiar AWS SDK commands. Inspect tables, send messages, upload objects — all without touching AWS.

58→
59→
60→ 61→
62→
63→
$0
64→

Zero Cost

65→

No AWS resources consumed during development. Your entire stack runs on your laptop.

66→
67→
68→
∅
69→

Zero Credentials

70→

No AWS access keys required. No risk of credential leaks or accidental production changes.

71→
72→
73→
Δ
74→

Zero Code Changes

75→

Standard AWS SDK calls work transparently. Your code runs identically locally and in production.

76→
77→
78→ 79→

Developer Experience

80→
81→
82→
🔄
83→

Hot Reloading

84→

Change your Lambda handlers and see the results instantly. File watchers detect changes and reload automatically — no restart needed.

85→
86→
87→
📊
88→

Web Dashboard

89→

Real-time web UI showing all resources, API routes, logs, and system status. Browse to http://localhost:3000/_ldk/gui to see everything at a glance.

90→
91→
92→
📝
93→

Structured Logging

94→

All Lambda invocations, API requests, and service calls logged in real-time. Stream logs directly in your terminal or via WebSocket to the dashboard.

95→
96→
97→
98→
99→ 100→
101→
102→

Why Use Local Web Services?

103→

Building with AWS CDK or Terraform traditionally means deploying to the cloud just to test your code. Every change triggers a deploy-wait-test cycle that kills your flow and racks up costs.

104→ 105→
106→
107→

Without Local Web Services

108→
    109→
  • Edit code
    • 110→
  • Run cdk deploy or terraform apply — wait minutes
    • 111→
  • Test against live AWS resources
    • 112→
  • Check CloudWatch logs for errors
    • 113→
  • Pay for every invocation and resource
    • 114→
  • Manage AWS credentials on every machine
    • 115→
  • Hope you don't break a shared environment
    • 116→
117→
118→
119→

With Local Web Services

120→
    121→
  • Edit code
    • 122→
  • Run uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev — ready in seconds
    • 123→
  • Edit code — hot reload picks up changes instantly
    • 124→
  • Test against local services
    • 125→
  • Use lws commands to inspect data
    • 126→
  • See logs directly in your terminal
    • 127→
  • Pay nothing
    • 128→
  • No credentials needed
    • 129→
  • Your own isolated environment
    • 130→
131→
132→
133→ 134→

Shift Left: Inner Loop Development

135→

Post-deployment testing is slow and expensive. Local Web Services moves testing into the inner loop — before deployment — enabling rapid iteration for developers and AI agents alike.

136→ 137→
138→
139→

Instant Feedback

140→

Edit your code and see the results immediately. Hot reloading picks up changes automatically — no restart, no redeploy, no waiting. The fastest feedback loop for cloud-native development.

141→
142→
143→

AI Agent Ready

144→

AI code editors need fast feedback loops to verify changes. Local Web Services eliminates deployment wait time, enabling AI agents to iterate and validate rapidly without AWS costs.

145→
146→
147→

Production Parity

148→

Your local environment mirrors your AWS architecture. The same services, the same APIs, the same integration patterns — so local testing actually predicts production behavior.

149→
150→

Zero AWS Dependency

Develop on a plane, in a coffee shop, or in a locked-down network. No AWS account needed, no credentials to manage, no risk of accidental production changes.

Complete Observability

CI/CD Testing

Run your full integration test suite in CI without provisioning real AWS resources. Fast, cheap, and reliable automated testing for your cloud-native apps.

How It Works

Local Web Services auto-detects your project type (CDK or Terraform) and starts local AWS-compatible service endpoints. Your code talks to local services instead of real AWS.

CDK Mode

Parse

177→

The ldk tool reads your cdk.out/ cloud assembly — the CloudFormation templates, construct tree, and asset paths that cdk synth produces.

178→
179→
180→
181→
2
182→
183→

Graph

184→

It builds a directed graph of your resources and their relationships: which Lambda is triggered by which API route, which function writes to which table, and what depends on what.

185→
186→
187→
188→
3
189→
190→

Start

191→

Local providers spin up in topological order — tables and queues first, then compute, then API gateways. Each service gets its own HTTP endpoint that speaks the AWS API.

192→
193→
194→
195→
4
196→
197→

Redirect

198→

The local runtime sets AWS_ENDPOINT_URL_* environment variables so the standard AWS SDK in your Lambda handlers automatically talks to the local services. No code changes needed.

199→
200→
201→
202→ 203→

Terraform Mode

204→
205→
206→
1
207→
208→

Detect

209→

The ldk tool detects .tf files in your project directory and enters Terraform mode automatically (or use --mode terraform explicitly).

210→
211→
212→
213→
2
214→
215→

Start All Services

216→

All AWS service providers start in always-on mode — DynamoDB, SQS, S3, SNS, EventBridge, Step Functions, Cognito, API Gateway, Lambda, IAM, STS, SSM Parameter Store, and Secrets Manager. Each service gets its own port.

217→
218→
219→
220→
3
221→
222→

Override

223→

A _lws_override.tf file is generated that redirects all AWS provider endpoints to your local services. This file is automatically added to .gitignore.

224→
225→
226→
227→
4
228→
229→

Apply

230→

Run terraform apply as normal. Terraform creates resources (tables, queues, buckets, Lambda functions) against your local endpoints. Your Lambda handlers run locally with full AWS SDK support.

231→
232→
233→
234→
235→
236→ 237→
238→
239→

Getting Started

240→

Get Local Web Services running with a sample project in under five minutes. Choose your IaC tool below.

241→ 242→

CDK Quick Start

243→ 244→
245→
246→

Prerequisites

247→
    248→
  • uv
    • 249→
  • Node.js 18+
    • 250→
  • AWS CDK CLI (npm install -g aws-cdk)
    • 251→
252→
253→ 254→
255→

1. Clone the sample project

256→
git clone https://github.com/local-web-services/sample-project.git 257→cd sample-project 258→npm install
259→
260→ 261→
262→

2. Synthesize the CDK app

263→
cdk synth
264→
265→ 266→
267→

3. Start the local environment

268→
uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev
269→

The ldk dev command reads the cloud assembly and starts local providers for every resource in the stack — DynamoDB tables, SQS queues, S3 buckets, Lambda functions, API Gateway, SSM parameters, and Secrets Manager secrets — all wired together.

270→

Once started, open http://localhost:3000/_ldk/gui to access the web dashboard with real-time logs, resource explorer, and system status.

271→
272→ 273→
274→

4. Make requests

275→
# Create an order via API Gateway 276→curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/orders \ 277→ -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ 278→ -d '{"customerName": "Jane", "items": ["Widget"], "total": 29.99}' 279→ 280→# Get the order 281→curl http://localhost:3000/orders/{orderId} 282→ 283→# Inspect data with lws 284→uvx --from local-web-services lws dynamodb scan --table-name OrdersTable 285→uvx --from local-web-services lws sqs receive-message --queue-name OrderQueue 286→uvx --from local-web-services lws s3api list-objects-v2 --bucket order-documents
287→

The sample project is an order processing system with API Gateway, Lambda, DynamoDB, SQS, SNS, S3, and Step Functions — all running on your machine. Use lws commands to inspect the data your application creates.

288→
289→
290→ 291→

Terraform Quick Start

292→ 293→
294→
295→

Prerequisites

296→
    297→
  • uv
    • 298→
  • Node.js 18+
    • 299→
  • Terraform >= 1.0
    • 300→
301→
302→ 303→
304→

1. Clone the Terraform sample project

305→
git clone https://github.com/local-web-services/sample-project-terraform.git 306→cd sample-project-terraform 307→cd lambda/create-order && npm install && cd ../.. 308→cd lambda/get-order && npm install && cd ../.. 309→cd lambda/process-order && npm install && cd ../.. 310→cd lambda/generate-receipt && npm install && cd ../..
311→
312→ 313→
314→

2. Initialize Terraform

315→
terraform init
316→
317→ 318→
319→

3. Start the local environment

320→
uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev
321→

The ldk dev command auto-detects your Terraform project, starts all AWS service providers in always-on mode, and generates a _lws_override.tf file that redirects Terraform's AWS provider to your local endpoints.

322→
323→ 324→
325→

4. Apply Terraform

326→

In another terminal, apply your Terraform configuration against the local services:

327→
terraform apply -auto-approve
328→

Terraform creates all resources (DynamoDB tables, SQS queues, Lambda functions, API Gateway routes, etc.) against your local endpoints. No AWS account needed.

329→
330→ 331→
332→

5. Test the application

333→
# Run the end-to-end test script 334→bash test-orders.sh 335→ 336→# Or test manually with lws commands 337→uvx --from local-web-services lws dynamodb scan --table-name Orders 338→uvx --from local-web-services lws stepfunctions start-execution \ 339→ --name OrderWorkflow \ 340→ --input '{"orderId": "test-123", "items": ["widget"], "total": 29.99}'
341→
342→
343→
344→
345→ 346→
347→
348→

Supported Services

349→

Each service provides AWS-compatible API operations emulated at runtime. In CDK mode, CDK constructs are parsed from your cdk synth output. In Terraform mode, all services start in always-on mode and resources are created dynamically via management APIs.

350→
351→
352→
353→

DynamoDB

354→
355→
356→

CDK Constructs

357→
358→ aws_dynamodb.Table 359→
360→

tableName, partitionKey, sortKey, globalSecondaryIndexes

361→
362→
363→

API Operations

364→
365→ PutItem 366→ GetItem 367→ DeleteItem 368→ UpdateItem 369→ Query 370→ Scan 371→ BatchGetItem 372→ BatchWriteItem 373→ CreateTable 374→ DeleteTable 375→ DescribeTable 376→ ListTables 377→ TransactGetItems 378→ TransactWriteItems 379→ UpdateTable 380→ DescribeContinuousBackups 381→ UpdateTimeToLive 382→
383→
384→

Backed by SQLite. Supports expression attribute names/values, filter expressions, and eventual consistency simulation.

385→
386→
387→
388→

SQS

389→
390→
391→

CDK Constructs

392→
393→ aws_sqs.Queue 394→
395→

queueName, fifo, visibilityTimeout, contentBasedDeduplication, deadLetterQueue

396→
397→
398→

API Operations

399→
400→ SendMessage 401→ ReceiveMessage 402→ DeleteMessage 403→ CreateQueue 404→ GetQueueUrl 405→ GetQueueAttributes 406→ SetQueueAttributes 407→ DeleteQueue 408→ ListQueues 409→ PurgeQueue 410→ SendMessageBatch 411→ DeleteMessageBatch 412→ ChangeMessageVisibility 413→ ChangeMessageVisibilityBatch 414→ ListDeadLetterSourceQueues 415→
416→
417→

Supports message attributes, long polling, and dead-letter queue wiring from RedrivePolicy.

418→
419→
420→
421→

S3

422→
423→
424→

CDK Constructs

425→
426→ aws_s3.Bucket 427→
428→

bucketName

429→
430→
431→

API Operations

432→
433→ PutObject 434→ GetObject 435→ DeleteObject 436→ HeadObject 437→ ListObjectsV2 438→ CreateBucket 439→ DeleteBucket 440→ HeadBucket 441→ ListBuckets 442→ CopyObject 443→ DeleteObjects 444→ PutBucketTagging 445→ GetBucketTagging 446→ DeleteBucketTagging 447→ GetBucketLocation 448→ PutBucketPolicy 449→ GetBucketPolicy

449→ GetBucketPolicy 450→ PutBucketNotificationConfiguration 451→ GetBucketNotificationConfiguration 452→ CreateMultipartUpload 453→ 454→ 455→

Backed by the local filesystem. Supports event notifications (ObjectCreated, ObjectRemoved), presigned URL generation, ETags, and content-type headers.

456→ 457→
458→
459→

SNS

460→
461→
462→

CDK Constructs

463→
464→ aws_sns.Topic 465→
466→

topicName. aws_sns.Subscription is not parsed — subscriptions are wired at runtime via the API or auto-wired by LDK for Lambda/SQS targets.

467→
468→
469→

API Operations

470→
471→ Publish 472→ Subscribe 473→ CreateTopic 474→ ListTopics 475→ ListSubscriptions 476→ DeleteTopic 477→ SetTopicAttributes 478→ Unsubscribe 479→ GetSubscriptionAttributes 480→ SetSubscriptionAttributes 481→ ConfirmSubscription 482→ ListSubscriptionsByTopic 483→
484→
485→

Supports Lambda and SQS subscription protocols, message attributes, and fan-out to multiple subscribers.

486→
487→
488→
489→

EventBridge

490→
491→
492→

CDK Constructs

493→
494→ aws_events.EventBus 495→ aws_events.Rule 496→
497→

eventBusName, ruleName, eventBus, eventPattern, schedule, targets

498→
499→
500→

API Operations

501→
502→ PutEvents 503→ PutRule 504→ PutTargets 505→ ListRules 506→ ListEventBuses 507→ RemoveTargets 508→ DeleteRule 509→ DescribeRule 510→ ListTargetsByRule 511→ EnableRule 512→ DisableRule 513→ TagResource 514→ UntagResource 515→ ListTagsForResource 516→
517→
518→

Supports event pattern matching, schedule expressions (rate and cron), Lambda targets, and input transformations.

519→
520→
521→
522→

Step Functions

523→
524→
525→

CDK Constructs

526→
527→ aws_stepfunctions.StateMachine 528→
529→

stateMachineName, definitionBody, stateMachineType

530→
531→
532→

API Operations

533→
534→ StartExecution 535→ StartSyncExecution 536→ DescribeExecution 537→ ListExecutions 538→ ListStateMachines 539→ CreateStateMachine 540→ StopExecution 541→ GetExecutionHistory 542→ UpdateStateMachine 543→
544→
545→

State types: Task, Pass, Choice, Wait, Succeed, Fail, Parallel, Map. Supports JSONPath (InputPath, OutputPath, ResultPath), error handling (Retry, Catch), and Standard & Express workflows.

546→
547→
548→
549→

Cognito

550→
551→
552→

CDK Constructs

553→
554→ aws_cognito.UserPool 555→ aws_cognito.UserPoolClient 556→
557→

userPoolName, lambdaTriggers (preAuthentication, postConfirmation), passwordPolicy, userPool

558→
559→
560→

API Operations

561→
562→ SignUp 563→ ConfirmSignUp 564→ InitiateAuth 565→ JWKS 566→ AdminCreateUser 567→ AdminDeleteUser 568→ AdminGetUser 569→ CreateUserPoolClient 570→ DeleteUserPoolClient 571→ DescribeUserPoolClient 572→ ListUserPoolClients 573→ UpdateUserPool 574→ ListUsers 575→ ForgotPassword 576→ ChangePassword 577→ GlobalSignOut 578→
579→
580→

Backed by SQLite. Supports JWT token generation (ID, access, refresh), user attributes, and password hashing.

581→
582→
583→
584→

Lambda

585→
586→
587→

CDK Constructs

588→
589→ aws_lambda.Function 590→
591→

handler, runtime, code, timeout, memorySize, environment

592→
593→
594→

Management API (Terraform mode)

595→
596→ CreateFunction 597→ GetFunction 598→ DeleteFunction 599→ ListFunctions 600→ Invoke 601→ UpdateFunctionConfiguration 602→ UpdateFunctionCode 603→ TagResource 604→ UntagResource 605→ ListEventSourceMappings 606→
607→
608→

Runs functions locally using Python or Node.js runtimes. Supports timeout enforcement, realistic context objects, and environment variable injection. In CDK mode, functions are discovered from the cloud assembly. In Terraform mode, functions are created dynamically via the management API.

609→
610→
611→
612→

API Gateway

613→
614→
615→

CDK Constructs

616→
617→ aws_apigateway.RestApi 618→ aws_apigatewayv2.HttpApi 619→
620→

routes, methods, integrations

621→
622→
623→

REST API (V1) Management

624→
625→ CreateRestApi 626→ GetRestApi 627→ DeleteRestApi 628→ CreateResource 629→ PutMethod 630→ PutIntegration 631→ CreateDeployment 632→ CreateStage 633→
634→
635→
636→

HTTP API (V2) Management

637→
638→ CreateApi 639→ GetApi 640→ DeleteApi 641→ CreateRoute 642→ CreateIntegration 643→ CreateStage 644→ ListRoutes 645→ ListIntegrations 646→ ListStages 647→
648→
649→

Supports both REST API (V1) and HTTP API (V2) with Lambda proxy integration. Routes requests to local Lambda functions with path parameters, query parameters, and request/response mapping. In Terraform mode, APIs and routes are created dynamically via the management API.

650→
651→
652→
653→

ECS

654→
655→
656→

CDK Constructs

657→
658→ aws_ecs.TaskDefinition 659→ aws_ecs.FargateService 660→ aws_ecs.Ec2Service 661→
662→

containerDefinitions, taskDefinition

663→
664→

Runs services as local subprocesses. Supports health checking, service discovery, file watching with auto-restart, and port mapping. Supports local command overrides via ldk.local_command metadata. CDK mode only.

665→
666→
667→
668→

IAM & STS

669→
670→
671→

IAM Operations

672→
673→ CreateRole 674→ GetRole 675→ DeleteRole 676→ CreatePolicy 677→ AttachRolePolicy 678→ PutRolePolicy 679→ ListRoles 680→ ListPolicies 681→
682→
683→
684→

STS Operations

685→
686→ GetCallerIdentity 687→ AssumeRole 688→
689→
690→

Stub APIs that return AWS-compatible responses for Terraform compatibility. IAM role and policy operations are accepted and stored in memory. STS returns dummy credentials and caller identity. These stubs allow terraform apply to succeed without a real AWS account.

691→
692→
693→
694→

SSM Parameter Store

695→
696→
697→

CDK Constructs

698→
699→ aws_ssm.StringParameter 700→
701→

Name, Type, Value, Description

702→
703→
704→

API Operations

705→
706→ PutParameter 707→ GetParameter 708→ GetParameters 709→ GetParametersByPath 710→ DeleteParameter 711→ DeleteParameters 712→ DescribeParameters 713→ AddTagsToResource 714→ RemoveTagsFromResource 715→ ListTagsForResource 716→
717→
718→

In-memory parameter store supporting String, StringList, and SecureString types with hierarchical paths, tagging, and version tracking. In CDK mode, parameters defined in the CloudFormation template are pre-seeded on startup.

719→
720→
721→
722→

Secrets Manager

723→
724→
725→

CDK Constructs

726→
727→ aws_secretsmanager.Secret 728→
729→

Name, Description, SecretString, GenerateSecretString

730→
731→
732→

API Operations

733→
734→ CreateSecret 735→ GetSecretValue 736→ PutSecretValue 737→ UpdateSecret 738→ DeleteSecret 739→ RestoreSecret 740→ ListSecrets 741→ DescribeSecret 742→ TagResource 743→ UntagResource 744→ ListSecretVersionIds 745→
746→
747→

In-memory secret store with version tracking (AWSCURRENT/AWSPREVIOUS staging labels), soft delete/restore, and tagging support. In CDK mode, secrets defined in the CloudFormation template are pre-seeded on startup.

748→

content.content:
748→ 749→ 750→ 751→ 752→ 753→
754→
755→

CLI Reference

756→

Complete command reference for both ldk and lws tools.

757→ 758→

LDK Commands

759→ 760→
761→
uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev [OPTIONS]
762→

ldk dev

763→

Start the full local environment with hot-reload. Watches your source files and restarts handlers on change.

764→
    765→
  • --port, -p API Gateway listen port (default: 3000)
    • 766→
  • --no-persist Disable data persistence — data is lost when ldk stops
    • 767→
  • --force-synth Force CDK synth even if cdk.out exists
    • 768→
  • --log-level, -l Log level: debug, info, warning, error (default: info)
    • 769→
  • --project-dir, -d Project root directory (default: current directory)
    • 770→
  • --mode, -m Project mode: cdk or terraform (default: auto-detect from project files)
    • 771→
772→
773→ 774→
775→
uvx --from local-web-services ldk invoke [OPTIONS]
776→

ldk invoke

777→

Invoke a Lambda function directly with a JSON event payload. Useful for testing handlers in isolation.

778→
    779→
  • --function-name, -f Lambda function name (required)
    • 780→
  • --event, -e Inline JSON event payload
    • 781→
  • --event-file Path to JSON event file
    • 782→
  • --project-dir, -d Project root directory (default: current directory)
    • 783→
  • --port, -p Management API port to connect to running ldk dev
    • 784→
785→
786→ 787→
788→
uvx --from local-web-services ldk reset [OPTIONS]
789→

ldk reset

790→

Clear all persisted local state — databases, queues, buckets. Start fresh.

791→
    792→
  • --yes, -y Skip confirmation prompt
    • 793→
  • --project-dir, -d Project root directory (default: current directory)
    • 794→
  • --port, -p Management API port to notify running ldk dev
    • 795→
796→
797→ 798→

LWS Commands

799→

AWS CLI-style commands for interacting with your local services. Requires a running ldk dev instance.

800→ 801→
802→
803→

lws status

804→

Show the status of the running ldk dev instance and all providers.

805→
uvx --from local-web-services lws status
806→
807→ 808→
809→

lws dynamodb

810→

DynamoDB table operations.

811→
812→ put-item 813→ get-item 814→ delete-item 815→ scan 816→ query 817→
818→
uvx --from local-web-services lws dynamodb scan \ 819→ --table-name MyTable
820→
821→ 822→
823→

lws sqs

824→

SQS queue operations.

825→
826→ send-message 827→ receive-message 828→ delete-message 829→ get-queue-attributes 830→
831→
uvx --from local-web-services lws sqs receive-message \ 832→ --queue-name MyQueue
833→
834→ 835→
836→

lws s3api

837→

S3 bucket operations.

838→
839→ put-object 840→ get-object 841→ delete-object 842→ list-objects-v2 843→ head-object 844→
845→
uvx --from local-web-services lws s3api list-objects-v2 \ 846→ --bucket my-bucket
847→
848→ 849→
850→

lws sns

851→

SNS topic operations.

852→
853→ publish 854→ list-topics 855→ list-subscriptions 856→
857→
uvx --from local-web-services lws sns publish \ 858→ --topic-name MyTopic \ 859→ --message "Hello"
860→
861→ 862→
863→

lws events

864→

EventBridge operations.

865→
866→ put-events 867→ list-rules 868→
869→
uvx --from local-web-services lws events put-events \ 870→ --entries '[{...}]'
871→
872→ 873→
874→

lws stepfunctions

875→

Step Functions operations.

876→
877→ start-execution 878→ describe-execution 879→ list-executions 880→ list-state-machines 881→
882→
uvx --from local-web-services lws stepfunctions start-execution \ 883→ --name MyStateMachine \ 884→ --input '{...}'
885→
886→ 887→
888→

lws cognito-idp

889→

Cognito User Pool operations.

890→
891→ sign-up 892→ confirm-sign-up 893→ initiate-auth 894→
895→
uvx --from local-web-services lws cognito-idp sign-up \ 896→ --user-pool-name MyPool \ 897→ --username user@example.com
898→
899→ 900→
901→

lws ssm

902→

SSM Parameter Store operations.

903→
904→ put-parameter 905→ get-parameter 906→ get-parameters-by-path 907→ delete-parameter 908→
909→
uvx --from local-web-services lws ssm put-parameter \ 910→ --name /app/config/key \ 911→ --value "my-value" \ 912→ --type String
913→
914→ 915→
916→

lws secretsmanager

917→

Secrets Manager operations.

918→
919→ create-secret 920→ get-secret-value 921→ put-secret-value 922→ list-secrets 923→
924→
uvx --from local-web-services lws secretsmanager create-secret \ 925→ --name MySecret \ 926→ --secret-string "my-secret-value"
927→
928→ 929→
930→

lws apigateway

931→

API Gateway test invocation.

932→
933→ test-invoke-method 934→
935→
uvx --from local-web-services lws apigateway test-invoke-method \ 936→ --resource /orders \ 937→ --http-method GET
938→
939→
940→
941→
942→ 943→
944→
945→
946→
947→ Local Web Services
